mainmatter.p: My name is 黄栩 (Huang Xu), but I go by the name Trebor online. I’m interested in (homotopy) type theory, category theory and jazz.

frontmatter.title: Dense subobject of a Lawvere–Tierney operator

mainmatter.p: Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator jjjj, a subobject F \hookrightarrow GF↪GF \hookrightarrow GF↪G is jjjj-dense if G \to \Omega \xrightarrow {j} \OmegaG→Ω→jΩG \to \Omega \xrightarrow {j} \OmegaG→Ωj​Ω is the constant true. In terms of the corresponding J \hookrightarrow \OmegaJ↪ΩJ \hookrightarrow \OmegaJ↪Ω, we need the pullback of it with G \to \OmegaG→ΩG \to \OmegaG→Ω to be \operatorname {id} : G \to Gid⁡:G→G\operatorname {id} : G \to Gid:G→G.

The exponentials of sheaves coincide with those of presheaves. To see this, we assume X^YXYX^YXY is the exponential of sheaves and calculate \begin {aligned} \Gamma (U, X^Y) &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Psh } }( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), X^Y) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X^Y) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }(Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }(Y^{++} \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }((Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U))^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Psh } }(Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), X) \\ \end {aligned}Γ(U,XY)=hom⁡Psh(よ(U),XY)=hom⁡Sh(よ(U)++,XY)=hom⁡Sh(Y×よ(U)++,X)=hom⁡Sh(Y++×よ(U)++,X)=hom⁡Sh((Y×よ(U))++,X)=hom⁡Psh(Y×よ(U),X)\begin {aligned} \Gamma (U, X^Y) &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Psh } }( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), X^Y) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X^Y) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }(Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }(Y^{++} \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Sh } }((Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U))^{++}, X) \\ &= \hom _{ \mathsf { Psh } }(Y \times \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), X) \\ \end {aligned}Γ(U,XY)​=homPsh​(よ(U),XY)=homSh​(よ(U)++,XY)=homSh​(Y×よ(U)++,X)=homSh​(Y++×よ(U)++,X)=homSh​((Y×よ(U))++,X)=homPsh​(Y×よ(U),X)​ which is evidently \Gamma (U, X^Y)Γ(U,XY)\Gamma (U, X^Y)Γ(U,XY) but this time the exponential is taken in the category of presheaves. We used the fact that the plus construction preserves finite product. However, we still need to prove that this indeed forms a sheaf.

Expressing the sheaf condition using Lawvere–Tierney operators, we only need to show for dense subobjects F \hookrightarrow GF↪GF \hookrightarrow GF↪G that \hom (G, X^Y) \to \hom (F, X^Y)hom⁡(G,XY)→hom⁡(F,XY)\hom (G, X^Y) \to \hom (F, X^Y)hom(G,XY)→hom(F,XY) is a bijection. This is equivalent to \hom (Y \times G, X) \to \hom (Y \times F, X).hom⁡(Y×G,X)→hom⁡(Y×F,X).\hom (Y \times G, X) \to \hom (Y \times F, X).hom(Y×G,X)→hom(Y×F,X). Note that the subobject Y \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times GY×F↪Y×GY \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times GY×F↪Y×G corresponds to the characteristic function Y \times G \to G \to \OmegaY×G→G→ΩY \times G \to G \to \OmegaY×G→G→Ω. Hence the denseness of F \hookrightarrow GF↪GF \hookrightarrow GF↪G implies the denseness of Y \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times GY×F↪Y×GY \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times GY×F↪Y×G. Since XXXX is a sheaf, we conclude that X^YXYX^YXY is also a sheaf.

Given a class of arrows SSSS, an SSSS-local object is an object XXXX such that for every f : A \to Bf:A→Bf : A \to Bf:A→B in SSSS, the composition map \hom (B, X) \to \hom (A, X)hom⁡(B,X)→hom⁡(A,X)\hom (B, X) \to \hom (A, X)hom(B,X)→hom(A,X) is an isomorphism.

Knowing the correspondence of Grothendieck coverages on \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C and Lawvere–Tierney operators on \mathsf { Psh } ( \mathcal { C } )Psh(C)\mathsf { Psh } ( \mathcal { C } )Psh(C), we naturally want to rewrite the sheaf condition to use Lawvere–Tierney operators instead of Grothendieck coverages.

Recall that the sheaf condition requires for every covering sieve S \hookrightarrow \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)S↪よ(U)S \hookrightarrow \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)S↪よ(U) that the composition \hom ( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), X) \to \hom (S, X)hom⁡(よ(U),X)→hom⁡(S,X)\hom ( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), X) \to \hom (S, X)hom(よ(U),X)→hom(S,X) is an isomorphism. We can reify this to a definition.

Given a class of arrows SSSS, an SSSS-local object is an object XXXX such that for every f : A \to Bf:A→Bf : A \to Bf:A→B in SSSS, the composition map \hom (B, X) \to \hom (A, X)hom⁡(B,X)→hom⁡(A,X)\hom (B, X) \to \hom (A, X)hom(B,X)→hom(A,X) is an isomorphism.

Now we just need to pick out the class of morphisms S \hookrightarrow \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)S↪よ(U)S \hookrightarrow \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)S↪よ(U) using the Lawvere–Tierney operator jjjj. Note that this operator does not necessarily live in a presheaf topos, so we must find a way to generalize this class of arrows to not necessarily representable presheaves. Since every presheaf is a colimit of representables, we can look at the corresponding colimit of morphisms \operatorname *{colim} S_i \hookrightarrow \operatorname *{colim} \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U_i)colim⁡Si↪colim⁡よ(Ui)\operatorname *{colim} S_i \hookrightarrow \operatorname *{colim} \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U_i)colimSi​↪colimよ(Ui​). A local object will satisfy \begin {aligned} \hom ( \operatorname *{colim} \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U_i), X) \cong \lim \hom ( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U_i), X) \quad \\ \xrightarrow { \sim } \lim \hom (S_i, X) \cong \hom ( \operatorname *{colim} S_i, X). \end {aligned}hom⁡(colim⁡よ(Ui),X)≅lim⁡hom⁡(よ(Ui),X)→∼lim⁡hom⁡(Si,X)≅hom⁡(colim⁡Si,X).\begin {aligned} \hom ( \operatorname *{colim} \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U_i), X) \cong \lim \hom ( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U_i), X) \quad \\ \xrightarrow { \sim } \lim \hom (S_i, X) \cong \hom ( \operatorname *{colim} S_i, X). \end {aligned}hom(colimよ(Ui​),X)≅limhom(よ(Ui​),X)∼​limhom(Si​,X)≅hom(colimSi​,X).​ Hence we can safely include these arrows into the class and still get the same concept of local objects. Now it's illuminating to look at the characteristic maps. A sieve S \to \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)S→よ(U)S \to \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U)S→よ(U) corresponds to a characteristic map in \hom ( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), \Omega ) \cong \Gamma (U, \Omega )hom⁡(よ(U),Ω)≅Γ(U,Ω)\hom ( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), \Omega ) \cong \Gamma (U, \Omega )hom(よ(U),Ω)≅Γ(U,Ω). Generalizing to an arbitrary presheaf expressed (canonically) as a colimit of representables, we need the image of every section to be a covering sieve.

frontmatter.title: Dense subobject of a Lawvere–Tierney operator

mainmatter.p: Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator jjjj, a subobject F \hookrightarrow GF↪GF \hookrightarrow GF↪G is jjjj-dense if G \to \Omega \xrightarrow {j} \OmegaG→Ω→jΩG \to \Omega \xrightarrow {j} \OmegaG→Ωj​Ω is the constant true. In terms of the corresponding J \hookrightarrow \OmegaJ↪ΩJ \hookrightarrow \OmegaJ↪Ω, we need the pullback of it with G \to \OmegaG→ΩG \to \OmegaG→Ω to be \operatorname {id} : G \to Gid⁡:G→G\operatorname {id} : G \to Gid:G→G.

In terms of sieves, for every section s \in \Gamma (U, G)s∈Γ(U,G)s \in \Gamma (U, G)s∈Γ(U,G), the sieve of arrows on UUUU along whom the restriction of ssss is in FFFF must be a covering sieve. We have arrived at the desired reformulation of the sheaf condition.
Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator jjjj, a jjjj-sheaf is defined as a jjjj-local object, i.e. a local object under the jjjj-dense monomorphisms.
Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator jjjj, a jjjj-sheaf is defined as a jjjj-local object, i.e. a local object under the jjjj-dense monomorphisms.
Consider a Lawvere–Tierney operator on a presheaf category. Then we may calculate the subobject classifier as in .

By the definition of subobject classifiers, a Lawvere–Tierney operator can be equivalently expressed as a subobject J \subseteq \OmegaJ⊆ΩJ \subseteq \OmegaJ⊆Ω. Translating the condition of preserving finite intersections, it needs to contain the improper sieve, be upwards closed and closed under finite intersections. And j \circ j = jj∘j=jj \circ j = jj∘j=j implies the following pullback square:

embedded-tex.embedded-tex-body: \begin {tikzcd} %tex J & J \\ \Omega & \Omega \arrow[hook, from=1-2, to=2-2] \arrow["j"', from=2-1, to=2-2] \arrow[hook, from=1-1, to=2-1] \arrow[from=1-1, to=1-2] \arrow["\lrcorner"{anchor=center, pos=0.125}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2] \end {tikzcd}

mainmatter.p: In other words, a sieve is contained in JJJJ iff its image under jjjj is also contained in JJJJ. Unfolding this, a sieve SSSS is contained in JJJJ iff the arrows gggg such that g^* Sg∗Sg^* Sg∗S is contained in JJJJ also form a sieve in JJJJ. Looking at the definition of a Grothendieck coverage, we see that they are equivalent, if we regard JJJJ as picking out the covering sieves.

Given a category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C, a Lawvere–Tierney operator is a morphism j : \Omega \to \Omegaj:Ω→Ωj : \Omega \to \Omegaj:Ω→Ω where \OmegaΩ\OmegaΩ is the subobject classifier, such that jjjj preserves finite intersections, and j \circ j = jj∘j=jj \circ j = jj∘j=j.

The subobject classifier \OmegaΩ\OmegaΩ of presheaves can be given by a quick calculation. \Gamma (U, \Omega ) \cong \hom ( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), \Omega ) \cong \operatorname {Sub}( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U))Γ(U,Ω)≅hom⁡(よ(U),Ω)≅Sub⁡(よ(U))\Gamma (U, \Omega ) \cong \hom ( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U), \Omega ) \cong \operatorname {Sub}( \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (U))Γ(U,Ω)≅hom(よ(U),Ω)≅Sub(よ(U)) By definition, this is the set of sieves on UUUU, and the functorial action is the pullback. For a monomorphism F \hookrightarrow GF↪GF \hookrightarrow GF↪G, an element s \in \Gamma (U, G)s∈Γ(U,G)s \in \Gamma (U, G)s∈Γ(U,G) is sent to the sieve consisting of arrows f : V \to Uf:V→Uf : V \to Uf:V→U such that the restriction along ffff is included in FFFF.
Given a Grothendieck coverage, the inclusion of separated presheaves to presheaves has a left adjoint (-)^ { \operatorname {sep}}(−)sep⁡(-)^ { \operatorname {sep}}(−)sep.

We define \Gamma (U, P^ { \operatorname {sep}} )Γ(U,Psep⁡)\Gamma (U, P^ { \operatorname {sep}} )Γ(U,Psep) to be a quotient of \Gamma (U, P)Γ(U,P)\Gamma (U, P)Γ(U,P). Two sections are considered the same if they are equal on a covering sieve. It is obvious that this is separated, and in a morphism P \to QP→QP \to QP→Q to a separated presheaf, if two sections of PPPP are equal on a covering sieve, then their image will also be, and by separatedness they must be actually equal in QQQQ.

frontmatter.title: Sheaf condition in terms of plus construction

mainmatter.p: Given a presheaf PPPP, the morphism P \to P^+P→P+P \to P^+P→P+ to its plus construction is a monomorphism iff PPPP is separated, and it is an isomorphism iff PPPP is a sheaf.
Sheafification is defined as the left adjoint of the inclusion from sheaves to the category of presheaves. Hence it freely constructs a sheaf from a presheaf.

We construct sheafification as an iterated plus construction. This produces a functor. By we have a natural bijection \hom (P^{++}, F) \cong \hom (P^+, F) \cong \hom (P, F).hom⁡(P++,F)≅hom⁡(P+,F)≅hom⁡(P,F).\hom (P^{++}, F) \cong \hom (P^+, F) \cong \hom (P, F).hom(P++,F)≅hom(P+,F)≅hom(P,F). Hence it is indeed the left adjoint. Since the bijections are given by composition with P \to P^+P→P+P \to P^+P→P+ and P^+ \to P^{++}P+→P++P^+ \to P^{++}P+→P++, we see that the unit of the adjunction is given by the composition P \to P^{++}P→P++P \to P^{++}P→P++.
Alternatively, using , we may compose two adjunctions to first separate the presheaf, and then perform the plus construction. By uniqueness of adjunction these two constructions are equivalent.

For any presheaf PPPP and sheaf FFFF, there is a natural bijection \hom (P, F) \cong \hom (P^+, F)hom⁡(P,F)≅hom⁡(P+,F)\hom (P, F) \cong \hom (P^+, F)hom(P,F)≅hom(P+,F) given by composition with \eta _P : P \to P^+ηP:P→P+\eta _P : P \to P^+ηP​:P→P+.
As a corollary of this and , when restricted to separated presheaves, it is left adjoint to the forgetful functor from sheaves to separated presheaves.

For every morphism P \to FP→FP \to FP→F, there is a unique way to extend the map to P^+P+P^+P+ using the sheaf condition of FFFF. A section of P^+P+P^+P+ consists of a matching family s_fsfs_fsf​, and it is also the gluing of \eta _P(s_f)ηP(sf)\eta _P(s_f)ηP​(sf​).

Given a category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C, a Grothendieck coverage declares some sieves to be coverings, such that The maximal sieve \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (A) \subseteq \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (A)よ(A)⊆よ(A)\mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (A) \subseteq \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (A)よ(A)⊆よ(A) is always a covering. Covering sieves are upwards closed, i.e. if S \subseteq S'S⊆S′S \subseteq S'S⊆S′ and SSSS is a covering sieve, then so is S'S′S'S′. If SSSS is a covering sieve of AAAA, and g : B \to Ag:B→Ag : B \to Ag:B→A is a morphism, then the pullback g^* Sg∗Sg^* Sg∗S is also a covering. Suppose SSSS is a sieve, then the collection of arrows gggg such that g^* Sg∗Sg^* Sg∗S is a covering is a sieve itself. If this sieve is a covering, then SSSS is also a covering. A Grothendieck coverage can be viewed as a coverage.

A coverage on an arbitrary category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C is given by a family of covers. A cover of some object AAAA in \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C is a family of maps with codomain AAAA. Given a cover f_i : U_i \to Afi:Ui→Af_i : U_i \to Afi​:Ui​→A and a map g : B \to Ag:B→Ag : B \to Ag:B→A, there is a cover of BBBB such that its composition with gggg is a refinement of f_ifif_ifi​, in the sense that every map in the cover factors through one of f_ifif_ifi​.

Given a category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C, a sieve SSSS and a presheaf P : \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Set }P:Cop→SetP : \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Set }P:Cop→Set, a set of descent data or a compatible family is a morphism S \to PS→PS \to PS→P. Expanding this, it is a family of local sections s \in \Gamma (U, P)s∈Γ(U,P)s \in \Gamma (U, P)s∈Γ(U,P) assigned for each morphism U \to AU→AU \to AU→A in the sieve SSSS, such that the local sections are compatible on restriction. There is an obvious map from the sections \Gamma (A, P)Γ(A,P)\Gamma (A, P)Γ(A,P) to the descent data given by restriction.

More generally, given a general cover, a set of descent data is a family of sections s_i \in \Gamma (U_i, P)si∈Γ(Ui,P)s_i \in \Gamma (U_i, P)si​∈Γ(Ui​,P) for each morphism f_i : U_i \to Afi:Ui→Af_i : U_i \to Afi​:Ui​→A in the cover, such that in any common restriction of U_iUiU_iUi​ and U_jUjU_jUj​, the sections agree. This can be equivalently expressed as the descent data of the sieve generated by the cover.

frontmatter.title: Iterated plus construction produces a sheaf

mainmatter.p: Given any presheaf PPPP, P^+P+P^+P+ is a separated presheaf, and if PPPP is already separated, P^+P+P^+P+ is a sheaf. Therefore P^{++}P++P^{++}P++ is always a sheaf.

We first prove that P^+P+P^+P+ is separated. Suppose there are two gluings of a set of descent data on a covering sieve SSSS over AAAA, then we have two sieves S_1, S_2S1,S2S_1, S_2S1​,S2​ over AAAA with compatible families s_{1, f}, s_{2, f}s1,f,s2,fs_{1, f}, s_{2, f}s1,f​,s2,f​. Since they are gluings of the same descent data, the restriction along any morphism g : U \to Ag:U→Ag : U \to Ag:U→A in SSSS would be equal. Hence there is a common refinement of g^* S_1g∗S1g^* S_1g∗S1​ and g^* S_2g∗S2g^* S_2g∗S2​ where the two families become equal. Expanding this, there is a covering sieve on UUUU such that g \circ h \in S_1 \cap S_2g∘h∈S1∩S2g \circ h \in S_1 \cap S_2g∘h∈S1​∩S2​ for every hhhh in the sieve, and s_{1, g \circ h} = s_{2, g \circ h}s1,g∘h=s2,g∘hs_{1, g \circ h} = s_{2, g \circ h}s1,g∘h​=s2,g∘h​. But then by the axioms of a Grothendieck coverage, g \circ hg∘hg \circ hg∘h for all hhhh in the said sieve and g \in Sg∈Sg \in Sg∈S also generates a covering sieve. Hence s_1s1s_1s1​ and s_2s2s_2s2​ are already equal on a covering subsieve, and so they are equal in \Gamma (A, P^+)Γ(A,P+)\Gamma (A, P^+)Γ(A,P+).

Let’s see why P^+P+P^+P+ is not necessarily a sheaf. To be a sheaf, we need to find a gluing for each compatible family. A compatible family of local sections of P^+P+P^+P+ is a family of covering sieves S_fSfS_fSf​ over UUUU for each morphism f : U \to Af:U→Af : U \to Af:U→A in SSSS, and for each S_fSfS_fSf​ a family of sections s_{f, g} \in \Gamma (V, P)sf,g∈Γ(V,P)s_{f, g} \in \Gamma (V, P)sf,g​∈Γ(V,P) where g : V \to Ug:V→Ug : V \to Ug:V→U lies in S_fSfS_fSf​. By the axioms of a Grothendieck coverage, the union \bigcup _{f \in S} f \circ S_f⋃f∈Sf∘Sf\bigcup _{f \in S} f \circ S_f⋃f∈S​f∘Sf​ is a sieve, since S_f \subseteq f^* (f \circ S_f)Sf⊆f∗(f∘Sf)S_f \subseteq f^* (f \circ S_f)Sf​⊆f∗(f∘Sf​). (Warning: f \circ S_ff∘Sff \circ S_ff∘Sf​ is not a covering sieve itself.) So we are tempted to simply construct a glued section s's′s's′ by s'_{f \circ g} = s_{f, g}sf∘g′=sf,gs'_{f \circ g} = s_{f, g}sf∘g′​=sf,g​. Hence we need to prove s_{f, g} = s_{f', g'}sf,g=sf′,g′s_{f, g} = s_{f', g'}sf,g​=sf′,g′​ if f \circ g = f' \circ g'f∘g=f′∘g′f \circ g = f' \circ g'f∘g=f′∘g′.

Since the families s_{f}sfs_{f}sf​ are compatible, given any g : V \to Ug:V→Ug : V \to Ug:V→U we have s_{f, g \circ r} = s_{f \circ g, r}sf,g∘r=sf∘g,rs_{f, g \circ r} = s_{f \circ g, r}sf,g∘r​=sf∘g,r​ for a family of arrows rrrr that generates a covering sieve on VVVV. However we cannot necessarily take r = \operatorname {id}r=id⁡r = \operatorname {id}r=id, so this is not necessarily well-defined. Here is where the separatedness comes in. Notice that s_{f, g \circ r} = s_{f \circ g, r}sf,g∘r=sf∘g,rs_{f, g \circ r} = s_{f \circ g, r}sf,g∘r​=sf∘g,r​ forms a compatible family over VVVV as rrrr ranges over the covering sieve. And therefore s_{f, g}sf,gs_{f, g}sf,g​ and s_{f \circ g, \operatorname {id} }sf∘g,id⁡s_{f \circ g, \operatorname {id} }sf∘g,id​ are both a gluing of the family. By separatedness, they must be equal. Hence our problem is solved.

Given a Grothendieck coverage on \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C and a presheaf P : \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Set }P:Cop→SetP : \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Set }P:Cop→Set, the plus construction produces a new presheaf P^+P+P^+P+ by taking a directed limit over all the descent data. More precisely, we assign \Gamma (A, P^+) = \operatorname *{colim} _{S \text { covers } A} \hom (S, P).Γ(A,P+)=colim⁡S covers Ahom⁡(S,P).\Gamma (A, P^+) = \operatorname *{colim} _{S \text { covers } A} \hom (S, P).Γ(A,P+)=S covers Acolim​hom(S,P). This means the sections of P^+P+P^+P+ are compatible families of sections of PPPP, and two families are considered equal if they are equal on a common covering subsieve.

Given a map g : B \to Ag:B→Ag : B \to Ag:B→A, we have a pullback \hom (S, P) \to \hom (g^*S, P)hom⁡(S,P)→hom⁡(g∗S,P)\hom (S, P) \to \hom (g^*S, P)hom(S,P)→hom(g∗S,P). This induces the functorial action of P^+P+P^+P+. There is an obvious natural transformation P \to P^+P→P+P \to P^+P→P+.

Given a sieve SSSS over AAAA and a morphism g : B \to Ag:B→Ag : B \to Ag:B→A, the pullback g^* Sg∗Sg^* Sg∗S is a sieve over BBBB. h : C \to Bh:C→Bh : C \to Bh:C→B is in this sieve iff g \circ hg∘hg \circ hg∘h is in SSSS. There is a natural map g^* S \to Sg∗S→Sg^* S \to Sg∗S→S given by g \circ -g∘−g \circ -g∘−.

Given a category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C equipped with a coverage, we define a presheaf P : \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Set }P:Cop→SetP : \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Set }P:Cop→Set to be a sheaf if it satisfies the sheaf condition: for every cover of AAAA, the map from sections of AAAA to descent data of the cover is a bijection. It is a separated presheaf if the map is an injection.

A sieve over an object AAAA of an arbitrary category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C is a subfunctor of \mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (A)よ(A)\mathop { \mkern {-2mu} \text {よ} \mkern {-2mu}} (A)よ(A). More explicitly, it selects some arrows with codomain AAAA, such that the selected arrows absorbs composition (i.e. if f : B \to Af:B→Af : B \to Af:B→A is selected and g : C \to Bg:C→Bg : C \to Bg:C→B, then g \circ fg∘fg \circ fg∘f is also selected).

frontmatter.title: \mathsf { Germ }Germ\mathsf { Germ }Germ is \mathsf { Filt }Filt\mathsf { Filt }Filt localized at inclusion maps of large subsets

mainmatter.p: The category of germs is equivalent to the category of filter spaces localized at maps of the form X \hookrightarrow YX↪YX \hookrightarrow YX↪Y, where XXXX is a large subset of YYYY, whose filter is induced by restriction from YYYY.

The filter spaces form another category, whose morphisms are germs, i.e. partial continuous functions defined on a large set, with equality considered up to some difference on a small set. This category is written \mathsf { Germ }Germ\mathsf { Germ }Germ.

A filter space is a set equipped with a filter. A morphism between germ spaces is a function such that the preimage of a large set is still large, which is often referred to as continuous. This creates a category \mathsf { Filt }Filt\mathsf { Filt }Filt.

Given a pair of chain reductions \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D and \rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D'ρ′:C′⇒⇒D′\rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D'ρ′:C′⇒⇒D′, we can construct a reduction from the mapping cone \operatorname {Cone} (f)Cone⁡(f)\operatorname {Cone} (f)Cone(f) of a chain map f : C \to C'f:C→C′f : C \to C'f:C→C′ to (the action of \rhoρ\rhoρ on ffff).

frontmatter.title: A space is noetherian iff hereditarily quasi-compact

mainmatter.p: A space is noetherian iff it is hereditarily quasi-compact, that is, if all its opens are quasi-compact.

We first show the forward direction. By the definition of being noetherian, all its opens are automatically noetherian. So we just need to prove that noetherian spaces are quasi-compact. This is obvious, since taking unions of the open covers we have an ascending chain of opens, which must terminate.

For the other direction, given an ascending chain of opens, they form a cover of their union. Since the union is an open, it is quasi-compact by hypothesis, and therefore the cover has a finite subcover, proving that the chain stabilizes after finitely many terms.

The intersections of two affine subschemes \operatorname {Spec} (R_1), \operatorname {Spec} (R_2) \hookrightarrow XSpec⁡(R1),Spec⁡(R2)↪X\operatorname {Spec} (R_1), \operatorname {Spec} (R_2) \hookrightarrow XSpec(R1​),Spec(R2​)↪X can be covered by affine schemes distinguished in both of them.

We just need to cover each point of the intersection. Suppose a point in the intersection is given by a prime ideal \mathfrak { p }p\mathfrak { p }p of R_1R1R_1R1​. We can pick a distinguished open D(f)D(f)D(f)D(f) of \operatorname {Spec} (R_2)Spec⁡(R2)\operatorname {Spec} (R_2)Spec(R2​) contained in the intersection and containing \mathfrak { p }p\mathfrak { p }p, and a distinguished open D(g)D(g)D(g)D(g) of \operatorname {Spec} (R_1)Spec⁡(R1)\operatorname {Spec} (R_1)Spec(R1​) contained in D(f)D(f)D(f)D(f) and containing \mathfrak { p }p\mathfrak { p }p. Now we prove that D(g)D(g)D(g)D(g) is a distinguished open in \operatorname {Spec} (R_2)Spec⁡(R2)\operatorname {Spec} (R_2)Spec(R2​).

It suffices to prove that D(g)D(g)D(g)D(g) is a distinguished open in \operatorname {Spec} (R_2 [f^{-1}])Spec⁡(R2[f−1])\operatorname {Spec} (R_2 [f^{-1}])Spec(R2​[f−1]), since this would imply the existence of an element g'/f^{n} \in R_2[f^{-1}]g′/fn∈R2[f−1]g'/f^{n} \in R_2[f^{-1}]g′/fn∈R2​[f−1], and we can take D(g') \cap D(f) = D(g' f)D(g′)∩D(f)=D(g′f)D(g') \cap D(f) = D(g' f)D(g′)∩D(f)=D(g′f) in \operatorname {Spec} (R_2)Spec⁡(R2)\operatorname {Spec} (R_2)Spec(R2​). Now there is an inclusion map \operatorname {Spec} (R_2[f^{-1}]) \to \operatorname {Spec} (R_1)Spec⁡(R2[f−1])→Spec⁡(R1)\operatorname {Spec} (R_2[f^{-1}]) \to \operatorname {Spec} (R_1)Spec(R2​[f−1])→Spec(R1​), which amounts to a ring homomorphism \varphiφ\varphiφ by . In this case, D( \varphi (g))D(φ(g))D( \varphi (g))D(φ(g)) is the required distinguished open, since \varphi ^{-1}D(u)φ−1D(u)\varphi ^{-1}D(u)φ−1D(u) is equal to D( \varphi (u))D(φ(u))D( \varphi (u))D(φ(u)) in \operatorname {Spec} (R_2 [f^{-1}])Spec⁡(R2[f−1])\operatorname {Spec} (R_2 [f^{-1}])Spec(R2​[f−1]).

Suppose a property on affine subschemes \operatorname {Spec} (R) \hookrightarrow XSpec⁡(R)↪X\operatorname {Spec} (R) \hookrightarrow XSpec(R)↪X is closed under taking distinguished subsets \operatorname {Spec} (R_f) \hookrightarrow XSpec⁡(Rf)↪X\operatorname {Spec} (R_f) \hookrightarrow XSpec(Rf​)↪X, and for \gcd \{ f_i \} = 1gcd⁡{fi}=1\gcd \{ f_i \} = 1gcd{fi​}=1, the property being true on \operatorname {Spec} (R_{f_i}) \hookrightarrow XSpec⁡(Rfi)↪X\operatorname {Spec} (R_{f_i}) \hookrightarrow XSpec(Rfi​​)↪X implies it being true on \operatorname {Spec} (R) \hookrightarrow XSpec⁡(R)↪X\operatorname {Spec} (R) \hookrightarrow XSpec(R)↪X. Then such a property is called affine local. We then say that XXXX has such a property if some affine cover has such a property: the result doesn’t depend on the chosen cover.

If the property PPPP only depends on \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R) and not XXXX (or the inclusion map), it can be simplified as a property on affine schemes. In this case, the above definition extends it to a property P'P′P'P′ on schemes, which we will usually refer to as locally PPPP. Suppose the scheme is furthermore quasi-compact, we say the scheme satisfies PPPP.

We prove that if some affine cover \{ \operatorname {Spec} (R_i) \hookrightarrow X \}{Spec⁡(Ri)↪X}\{ \operatorname {Spec} (R_i) \hookrightarrow X \}{Spec(Ri​)↪X} has such a property, then all the affine subschemes has it, hence we can check on any affine cover. Given an affine subscheme \operatorname {Spec} (S) \hookrightarrow XSpec⁡(S)↪X\operatorname {Spec} (S) \hookrightarrow XSpec(S)↪X, using Nike’s trick, we see that the intersection with \operatorname {Spec} (R_i)Spec⁡(Ri)\operatorname {Spec} (R_i)Spec(Ri​) is covered by affine subschemes, which will all have the said property. Hence we get a cover of \operatorname {Spec} (S) \hookrightarrow XSpec⁡(S)↪X\operatorname {Spec} (S) \hookrightarrow XSpec(S)↪X with the said property, and therefore itself also.
A space is irreducible iff finitely many non-empty opens always has non-empty intersection. In other words, iff it is non-empty and cannot be written as a union of two closed sets.

frontmatter.title: Adjunction of global section and \operatorname {Spec}Spec⁡\operatorname {Spec}Spec

mainmatter.p: We have an adjunction of functors \mathsf { CRing } ^ \textrm {op} \xtofrom [ \Gamma ( \top , \mathscr { O } _{(-)})]{ \operatorname {Spec} } \mathsf { Sch } ,CRingop⇄Γ(⊤,O(−))Spec⁡Sch,\mathsf { CRing } ^ \textrm {op} \xtofrom [ \Gamma ( \top , \mathscr { O } _{(-)})]{ \operatorname {Spec} } \mathsf { Sch } ,CRingopSpecΓ(⊤,O(−)​)​Sch, with \operatorname {Spec}Spec⁡\operatorname {Spec}Spec being the right adjoint (or \operatorname {Spec} : \mathsf { CRing } \to \mathsf { Sch } ^ \textrm {op}Spec⁡:CRing→Schop\operatorname {Spec} : \mathsf { CRing } \to \mathsf { Sch } ^ \textrm {op}Spec:CRing→Schop being the left adjoint). In fact, we can replace \mathsf { Sch }Sch\mathsf { Sch }Sch with the category of locally ringed spaces \mathsf { LRS }LRS\mathsf { LRS }LRS, of whom \mathsf { Sch }Sch\mathsf { Sch }Sch is a full subcategory.

We need to give a natural bijection \hom (X, \operatorname {Spec} (R)) \cong \hom (R, \Gamma ( \top , \mathscr { O } _X)).hom⁡(X,Spec⁡(R))≅hom⁡(R,Γ(⊤,OX)).\hom (X, \operatorname {Spec} (R)) \cong \hom (R, \Gamma ( \top , \mathscr { O } _X)).hom(X,Spec(R))≅hom(R,Γ(⊤,OX​)). In other words, maps X \to \operatorname {Spec} (R)X→Spec⁡(R)X \to \operatorname {Spec} (R)X→Spec(R) between locally ringed spaces are uniquely specified by the action of global sections.

Since XXXX is glued from affine open subschemes, a map from XXXX is equivalent to a map from each open subscheme \operatorname {Spec} (S_i)Spec⁡(Si)\operatorname {Spec} (S_i)Spec(Si​) that agree on common restrictions (which again can be checked on an affine covering). Since the codomain is affine, these maps are equivalently ring homomorphisms R \to S_iR→SiR \to S_iR→Si​ by . The elements of \Gamma ( \top , \mathscr { O } _X)Γ(⊤,OX)\Gamma ( \top , \mathscr { O } _X)Γ(⊤,OX​) are also given by a set of compatible elements from S_iSiS_iSi​. Hence these two sets are naturally bijective.

frontmatter.title: Characterization of the locale \operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj⁡(S)\operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj(S)

mainmatter.p: The opens of the projective spectrum \operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj⁡(S)\operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj(S) are in bijection with graded radical ideals with \mathfrak { r } _0 = 0r0=0\mathfrak { r } _0 = 0r0​=0. Hence we write D_+ ( \mathfrak { r } )D+(r)D_+ ( \mathfrak { r } )D+​(r) for this open. The proof is exactly the same as .

To define projective spaces, we start with an affine space, and restricts ourselves to regions invariant under dilation — or using the language of points, we consider lines through the origin as points. Hence we need to define how an element of a ring (which is geometrically a function on the affine space) behaves under dilation.

In polynomial rings, for example, the polynomial x^2 + 2y + 7x2+2y+7x^2 + 2y + 7x2+2y+7 becomes \lambda ^2 x^2 + 2 \lambda y + 7λ2x2+2λy+7\lambda ^2 x^2 + 2 \lambda y + 7λ2x2+2λy+7 under a dilation by \lambdaλ\lambdaλ. Note how each term can be classified by the power of \lambdaλ\lambdaλ it obtains. Hence, what we need is a grading on the ring, which partitions R = \bigoplus _d R_dR=⨁dRdR = \bigoplus _d R_dR=⨁d​Rd​ (as abelian groups). R_dRdR_dRd​ is intuitively the elements that get the factor \lambda ^dλd\lambda ^dλd upon dilation. The multiplication of a degree pppp element with a degree qqqq element should produce a degree (p+q)(p+q)(p+q)(p+q) element, since \lambda ^p \lambda ^q = \lambda ^{p+q}λpλq=λp+q\lambda ^p \lambda ^q = \lambda ^{p+q}λpλq=λp+q.

A D-graded ring is a sequence of abelian groups R_dRdR_dRd​, where d \in Dd∈Dd \in Dd∈D are elements of a commutative monoid called the grading. We have a bilinear multiplication map R_p \otimes R_q \to R_{p+q}Rp⊗Rq→Rp+qR_p \otimes R_q \to R_{p+q}Rp​⊗Rq​→Rp+q​ and a identity element 1 \in R_01∈R01 \in R_01∈R0​ satisfying the associativity and identity laws.
Usually, the grading is one of \mathbb ZZ\mathbb ZZ or \mathbb NN\mathbb NN. A bigraded ring is graded over D^2D2D^2D2 instead of DDDD, whatever the context implies the grading is.

The opens of a projective space should come from the non-vanishing region of a homogeneous function, i.e. elements with a single degree. This ensures that dilation doesn’t change the opens. However, we would have multiple ways to represent the entire space: in a two-dimensional affine space, D(x) \cup D(y)D(x)∪D(y)D(x) \cup D(y)D(x)∪D(y) and D(1)D(1)D(1)D(1) are both invariant under dilation, but the former excludes the origin, while the latter does not. In a projective setting, we don’t care about the origin at all, and considering that all homogeneous polynomials of positive degree vanish at the origin, we should make that mandatory. Hence, we only consider the opens corresponding to positively graded elements, which we write as D_+ (f)D+(f)D_+ (f)D+​(f). We can construct a space similar to the localic spectrum of a commutative ring.

frontmatter.title: Projective spectrum of a graded ring

mainmatter.p: Given a \mathbb NN\mathbb NN-graded ring S_ \bulletS∙S_ \bulletS∙​, we construct a locale analogous to the \operatorname {Spec}Spec⁡\operatorname {Spec}Spec construction for affine schemes. We start with symbols of distinguished opens D_+ (f)D+(f)D_+ (f)D+​(f) for each positively graded element ffff, and impose the same relations: D_+D+D_+D+​ sends finite products to finite intersections, and for elements of the same grade, D_+ ( \sum _i f_i) \subseteq \bigcup _i D_+(f_i)D+(∑ifi)⊆⋃iD+(fi)D_+ ( \sum _i f_i) \subseteq \bigcup _i D_+(f_i)D+​(∑i​fi​)⊆⋃i​D+​(fi​).

As for the structure sheaf, we need to decide what the sections over D_+ (f)D+(f)D_+ (f)D+​(f) are. They should be functions defined on the affine space D(f) \subseteq \operatorname {Spec} (S)D(f)⊆Spec⁡(S)D(f) \subseteq \operatorname {Spec} (S)D(f)⊆Spec(S), but invariant under dilation. Note that it is stronger than requiring vanishing region be invariant. We actually need the grade 0000 elements here. Recalling from structure sheaf of a ring spectrum that \Gamma (D(f), \mathscr { O } _{ \operatorname {Spec} (S)}) = S[f^{-1}]Γ(D(f),OSpec⁡(S))=S[f−1]\Gamma (D(f), \mathscr { O } _{ \operatorname {Spec} (S)}) = S[f^{-1}]Γ(D(f),OSpec(S)​)=S[f−1] (which can be given a canonical grading since ffff is a graded element), we can make the following definition.

mainmatter.p: Fix a graded ring SSSS. For a positively graded element ffff, we have a graded ring localization S[f^{-1}]_ \bulletS[f−1]∙S[f^{-1}]_ \bulletS[f−1]∙​. Let \Gamma (D_+(f), \mathscr { O } )Γ(D+(f),O)\Gamma (D_+(f), \mathscr { O } )Γ(D+​(f),O) be the zeroth degree component S[f^{-1}]_0S[f−1]0S[f^{-1}]_0S[f−1]0​. This defines a sheaf over the projective spectrum, and moreover gives a scheme \operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj⁡(S)\operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj(S).

We claim that \operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj⁡(S)\operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj(S) can alternatively be given by gluing affine schemes. We assign D_+ (f)D+(f)D_+ (f)D+​(f) the affine scheme \operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec⁡(S[f−1]0)\operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec(S[f−1]0​) (which is possible because the open subspace D_+ (f)D+(f)D_+ (f)D+​(f) is homeomorphic to \operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec⁡(S[f−1]0)\operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec(S[f−1]0​) as a space). Given two positively graded elements ffff and gggg, we have an isomorphism between \operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj⁡(S)\operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj(S) restricted to D_+ (f g)D+(fg)D_+ (f g)D+​(fg) and \operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec⁡(S[f−1]0)\operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec(S[f−1]0​) restricted to D(g^{ \deg f}/f^{ \deg g})D(gdeg⁡f/fdeg⁡g)D(g^{ \deg f}/f^{ \deg g})D(gdegf/fdegg), given by the obvious ring isomorphism. We can verify that this satisfies the cocycle condition, and hence defines a scheme.

A D-graded ring is a sequence of abelian groups R_dRdR_dRd​, where d \in Dd∈Dd \in Dd∈D are elements of a commutative monoid called the grading. We have a bilinear multiplication map R_p \otimes R_q \to R_{p+q}Rp⊗Rq→Rp+qR_p \otimes R_q \to R_{p+q}Rp​⊗Rq​→Rp+q​ and a identity element 1 \in R_01∈R01 \in R_01∈R0​ satisfying the associativity and identity laws.
Usually, the grading is one of \mathbb ZZ\mathbb ZZ or \mathbb NN\mathbb NN. A bigraded ring is graded over D^2D2D^2D2 instead of DDDD, whatever the context implies the grading is.
Given a \mathbb NN\mathbb NN-graded ring SSSS, its irrelevant ideal \mathord { \odot }⊙\mathord { \odot }⊙ is defined by the subset S_+S+S_+S+​ of all positively graded elements.

The points of the projective scheme \operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj⁡(S)\operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj(S) are given by prime ideals not dividing the irrelevant ideal \mathord { \odot }⊙\mathord { \odot }⊙. This is in bijection with ideals with \mathfrak { p } _0 = 0p0=0\mathfrak { p } _0 = 0p0​=0 (equivalently \mathord { \odot } \nmid \mathfrak { p }⊙∤p\mathord { \odot } \nmid \mathfrak { p }⊙∤p), and the condition for prime ideals holds for positively graded elements, i.e. \mathfrak { p } \mid x y \iff ( \mathfrak { p } \mid x \lor \mathfrak { p } \mid y)p∣xy  ⟺  (p∣x∨p∣y)\mathfrak { p } \mid x y \iff ( \mathfrak { p } \mid x \lor \mathfrak { p } \mid y)p∣xy⟺(p∣x∨p∣y) for positively graded xxxx and yyyy.

To specify a point PPPP, we need to specify which opens D_+(f)D+(f)D_+(f)D+​(f) it belongs to, where ffff ranges over positively graded elements. Equivalently, we specify the closeds V_+(f)V+(f)V_+(f)V+​(f). Since V_+(f) \cap V_+(g) \subseteq V_+(f + g)V+(f)∩V+(g)⊆V+(f+g)V_+(f) \cap V_+(g) \subseteq V_+(f + g)V+​(f)∩V+​(g)⊆V+​(f+g), if P \in V_+(f)P∈V+(f)P \in V_+(f)P∈V+​(f) and P \in V_+(g)P∈V+(g)P \in V_+(g)P∈V+​(g) then P \in V_+(f + g)P∈V+(f+g)P \in V_+(f + g)P∈V+​(f+g). Similarly since V_+(f) \subseteq V_+(f g)V+(f)⊆V+(fg)V_+(f) \subseteq V_+(f g)V+​(f)⊆V+​(fg), P \in V_+(f)P∈V+(f)P \in V_+(f)P∈V+​(f) implies P \in V_+(f g)P∈V+(fg)P \in V_+(f g)P∈V+​(fg). Collecting all the elements whose distinguished closed contains PPPP, we get an ideal \mathfrak { a }a\mathfrak { a }a whose zeroth degree vanishes.

We have V_+(f g) = V_+(f) \cup V_+(g)V+(fg)=V+(f)∪V+(g)V_+(f g) = V_+(f) \cup V_+(g)V+​(fg)=V+​(f)∪V+​(g), so if \mathfrak { a } \mid f ga∣fg\mathfrak { a } \mid f ga∣fg, then either \mathfrak { a } \mid fa∣f\mathfrak { a } \mid fa∣f or \mathfrak { a } \mid ga∣g\mathfrak { a } \mid ga∣g. This is almost the condition for prime ideals, but recall that ffff and gggg must have positive grading, so we actually get the ideals in the theorem statement. Conversely, being such an ideal is sufficient condition for the specification of the point to be valid, by calculation with .

Next, we prove these ideals are in bijection with prime ideals not dividing \mathord { \odot }⊙\mathord { \odot }⊙. One direction of the correspondence is obvious: we take a prime ideal \mathfrak { p }p\mathfrak { p }p and remove the zeroth degree, which amounts to taking \operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { p } , \mathord { \odot } )lcm⁡(p,⊙)\operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { p } , \mathord { \odot } )lcm(p,⊙).

We prove injectivity. Suppose primes \mathfrak { p }p\mathfrak { p }p and \mathfrak { q }q\mathfrak { q }q satisfy \operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { p } , \mathord { \odot } ) = \operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { q } , \mathord { \odot } )lcm⁡(p,⊙)=lcm⁡(q,⊙)\operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { p } , \mathord { \odot } ) = \operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { q } , \mathord { \odot } )lcm(p,⊙)=lcm(q,⊙), then \mathfrak { p } \mid \operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { q } , \mathord { \odot } ) \mid \mathfrak { q } \cdot \mathord { \odot }p∣lcm⁡(q,⊙)∣q⋅⊙\mathfrak { p } \mid \operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { q } , \mathord { \odot } ) \mid \mathfrak { q } \cdot \mathord { \odot }p∣lcm(q,⊙)∣q⋅⊙, so either \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathord { \odot }p∣⊙\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathord { \odot }p∣⊙ which is forbidden, or \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { q }p∣q\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { q }p∣q. Conversely we must have \mathfrak { q } \mid \mathfrak { p }q∣p\mathfrak { q } \mid \mathfrak { p }q∣p, hence \mathfrak { p } = \mathfrak { q }p=q\mathfrak { p } = \mathfrak { q }p=q.

We prove surjectivity. Given an ideal \mathfrak { a }a\mathfrak { a }a, we need to supplement it with a zeroth degree component \mathfrak { a } _0a0\mathfrak { a } _0a0​ so that together they make a prime ideal not divided by \mathord { \odot }⊙\mathord { \odot }⊙. We define \mathfrak { a } _0 \mid ca0∣c\mathfrak { a } _0 \mid ca0​∣c iff there exists some positively graded \mathfrak { a } \nmid fa∤f\mathfrak { a } \nmid fa∤f such that \mathfrak { a } \mid cfa∣cf\mathfrak { a } \mid cfa∣cf. The verification is routine element chasing.

We claim that \operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj⁡(S)\operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj(S) can alternatively be given by gluing affine schemes. We assign D_+ (f)D+(f)D_+ (f)D+​(f) the affine scheme \operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec⁡(S[f−1]0)\operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec(S[f−1]0​) (which is possible because the open subspace D_+ (f)D+(f)D_+ (f)D+​(f) is homeomorphic to \operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec⁡(S[f−1]0)\operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec(S[f−1]0​) as a space). Given two positively graded elements ffff and gggg, we have an isomorphism between \operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj⁡(S)\operatorname {Proj} (S)Proj(S) restricted to D_+ (f g)D+(fg)D_+ (f g)D+​(fg) and \operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec⁡(S[f−1]0)\operatorname {Spec} (S[f^{-1}]_0)Spec(S[f−1]0​) restricted to D(g^{ \deg f}/f^{ \deg g})D(gdeg⁡f/fdeg⁡g)D(g^{ \deg f}/f^{ \deg g})D(gdegf/fdegg), given by the obvious ring isomorphism. We can verify that this satisfies the cocycle condition, and hence defines a scheme.

frontmatter.title: Action of morphisms on stalks of locally ringed spaces

mainmatter.p: Given a morphism of ringed spaces \varphi : X \to Yφ:X→Y\varphi : X \to Yφ:X→Y, if it is local, a germ is invertible iff its pullback under \varphiφ\varphiφ is invertible. If the space XXXX has enough points, then the inverse implication is also true.

Note that the stalk ( \varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _{Y})_x = \mathscr { O } _{Y, \varphi (x)}(φ−1OY)x=OY,φ(x)( \varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _{Y})_x = \mathscr { O } _{Y, \varphi (x)}(φ−1OY​)x​=OY,φ(x)​. A germ being invertible implies for some neighborhood UUUU of xxxx, it comes from an invertible section f \in \Gamma (U, \varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _Y)f∈Γ(U,φ−1OY)f \in \Gamma (U, \varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _Y)f∈Γ(U,φ−1OY​), so the image in \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } _X)Γ(U,OX)\Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } _X)Γ(U,OX​) is also invertible, and hence the image germ. The locality condition gives the converse.
On the other hand, if the space has enough points, then being invertible at each stalk implies being invertible. This is enough to guarantee logical equivalence.

Morphism of affine schemes are in natural bijection with ring homomorphisms in the opposite direction. In other words, there is a fully faithful embedding \mathsf { CRing } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Sch }CRingop→Sch\mathsf { CRing } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Sch }CRingop→Sch.

Given two rings RRRR, SSSS, a ring homomorphism \varphi : S \to Rφ:S→R\varphi : S \to Rφ:S→R naturally induces a map of distinguished opens f \mapsto \varphi (f)f↦φ(f)f \mapsto \varphi (f)f↦φ(f). This is a continuous map \operatorname {Spec} (R) \to \operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec⁡(R)→Spec⁡(S)\operatorname {Spec} (R) \to \operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec(R)→Spec(S), because \varphiφ\varphiφ preserves \operatorname {lcm}lcm⁡\operatorname {lcm}lcm and \gcdgcd⁡\gcdgcd on radical ideals. For the structure sheaf, we can use the distinguished basis, thus we need to supply a ring homomorphism \Gamma (D(s), \mathscr { O } _{ \operatorname {Spec} (S)}) \to \Gamma (D(r), \mathscr { O } _{ \operatorname {Spec} (R)})Γ(D(s),OSpec⁡(S))→Γ(D(r),OSpec⁡(R))\Gamma (D(s), \mathscr { O } _{ \operatorname {Spec} (S)}) \to \Gamma (D(r), \mathscr { O } _{ \operatorname {Spec} (R)})Γ(D(s),OSpec(S)​)→Γ(D(r),OSpec(R)​) whenever D(r) \subseteq \varphi ^{-1}D(s) = D( \varphi (s))D(r)⊆φ−1D(s)=D(φ(s))D(r) \subseteq \varphi ^{-1}D(s) = D( \varphi (s))D(r)⊆φ−1D(s)=D(φ(s)). This is just a homomorphism S[s^{-1}] \to R[r^{-1}]S[s−1]→R[r−1]S[s^{-1}] \to R[r^{-1}]S[s−1]→R[r−1], which is obvious because \varphi (s)φ(s)\varphi (s)φ(s) must be invertible in R[r^{-1}]R[r−1]R[r^{-1}]R[r−1].

We need to prove our map is local. Using the characterization on stalks, we just need to verify that S_{ \varphi ^{-1}( \mathfrak { p } )} \to R_{ \mathfrak { p } }Sφ−1(p)→RpS_{ \varphi ^{-1}( \mathfrak { p } )} \to R_{ \mathfrak { p } }Sφ−1(p)​→Rp​ reflects invertibility. This is true by construction. Hence we have a map \hom _{ \mathsf { CRing } }(S, R) \to \hom _{ \mathsf { Sch } }( \operatorname {Spec} (R), \operatorname {Spec} (S))hom⁡CRing(S,R)→hom⁡Sch(Spec⁡(R),Spec⁡(S))\hom _{ \mathsf { CRing } }(S, R) \to \hom _{ \mathsf { Sch } }( \operatorname {Spec} (R), \operatorname {Spec} (S))homCRing​(S,R)→homSch​(Spec(R),Spec(S)).

In the reverse direction, given a morphism \varphi : \operatorname {Spec} (R) \to \operatorname {Spec} (S)φ:Spec⁡(R)→Spec⁡(S)\varphi : \operatorname {Spec} (R) \to \operatorname {Spec} (S)φ:Spec(R)→Spec(S), we can extract a ring homomorphism by looking at the global sections S \cong \Gamma ( \top , \varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _{ \operatorname {Spec} (S)}) \to \Gamma ( \top , \mathscr { O } _{ \operatorname {Spec} (R)}) \cong R.S≅Γ(⊤,φ−1OSpec⁡(S))→Γ(⊤,OSpec⁡(R))≅R.S \cong \Gamma ( \top , \varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _{ \operatorname {Spec} (S)}) \to \Gamma ( \top , \mathscr { O } _{ \operatorname {Spec} (R)}) \cong R.S≅Γ(⊤,φ−1OSpec(S)​)→Γ(⊤,OSpec(R)​)≅R. We obviously have going from \mathsf { CRing }CRing\mathsf { CRing }CRing to \mathsf { Sch }Sch\mathsf { Sch }Sch and then back is the identity. For the other direction, we first claim that the global section ring homomorphism (and the topological map) completely determines the morphism. Indeed, we need a commutative diagram:

mainmatter.p: where \left [ \mathfrak { q } \right ][q]\left [ \mathfrak { q } \right ][q] is the image of the point \left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p]\left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p] under the underlying continuous map of \varphiφ\varphiφ. This fixes the action of \varphiφ\varphiφ on the stalks. Furthermore, the locality implies the preimage of \mathfrak { p }p\mathfrak { p }p under the ring homomorphism divides \mathfrak { q }q\mathfrak { q }q, and since \mathfrak { q }q\mathfrak { q }q is maximal in the local ring S_{ \mathfrak { q } }SqS_{ \mathfrak { q } }Sq​, the two ideals are equal. Hence the ring homomorphism determines the topological map too. This finishes the proof.

In general, a pullback is any contravariant functorial action. In other words, we have a functor F : \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathcal { D }F:Cop→DF : \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathcal { D }F:Cop→D, and pulling back along a morphism ffff in \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C means the action of F(f)F(f)F(f)F(f).

In differential geometry, we have a set of kkkk-forms \Omega ^k(M)Ωk(M)\Omega ^k(M)Ωk(M), which forms a functor \mathsf { Mfd } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Set }Mfdop→Set\mathsf { Mfd } ^ \textrm {op} \to \mathsf { Set }Mfdop→Set. Pullbacks of differential forms is then the functorial action. In the special case of k = 0k=0k = 0k=0, this corresponds to composition, which is sometimes also referred to as pullbacks.

The categorical pullback can also be construed as a contravariant action, which forms the functor from \mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op}Cop\mathcal { C } ^ \textrm {op}Cop to the 2222-category \mathsf { Cat }Cat\mathsf { Cat }Cat given by taking slices.

mainmatter.p: Note that the subsheaf of units is given by a finite limit, hence \varphi ^{-1}φ−1\varphi ^{-1}φ−1 preserves it. Since the lower map map \varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _Y \to \mathscr { O } _Xφ−1OY→OX\varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _Y \to \mathscr { O } _Xφ−1OY​→OX​ is a ring homomorphism on the sections, it maps units to units. Hence restriction to the upper map makes sense.

Given a sheaf \mathscr { O }O\mathscr { O }O of rings, we can define a subsheaf \mathscr { O } ^ \timesO×\mathscr { O } ^ \timesO× consisting of the invertible elements, i.e. \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } ^ \times ) = \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )^ \timesΓ(U,O×)=Γ(U,O)×\Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } ^ \times ) = \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )^ \timesΓ(U,O×)=Γ(U,O)×. This is the subsheaf of units.

This can be equivalently expressed as a pullback of \mathscr { O } \times \mathscr { O } \xrightarrow {(f,g) \mapsto f g} \mathscr { O }O×O→(f,g)↦fgO\mathscr { O } \times \mathscr { O } \xrightarrow {(f,g) \mapsto f g} \mathscr { O }O×O(f,g)↦fg​O and 1 \xrightarrow {1} \mathscr { O }1→1O1 \xrightarrow {1} \mathscr { O }11​O.
An affine scheme is a locally ringed space of the form \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R) for some commutative ring RRRR.
The locality requirement for a ringed space is to guarantee that the sections behave like functions valued in some field.

It is impossible in general to discuss the vanishing region of a section f \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )f∈Γ(U,O)f \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )f∈Γ(U,O). For instance, the germs of continuous functions are non-zero on their support, which is the closure of the non-vanishing region. In algebraic geometry, such an overspill destroys most valuable information. We can talk about the maximal region on which the section is invertible, but this is different from being non-zero if sections don’t behave like functions. Similarly, it is also impossible to discuss the value of a section at some point in general. In locally ringed space, we have .

Given two ringed spaces X, YX,YX, YX,Y, a morphism \varphi : X \to Yφ:X→Y\varphi : X \to Yφ:X→Y is given by a continuous map of the underlying spaces, and a sheaf morphism \varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _Y \to \mathscr { O } _Xφ−1OY→OX\varphi ^{-1} \mathscr { O } _Y \to \mathscr { O } _Xφ−1OY​→OX​, equivalently \mathscr { O } _Y \to \varphi _* \mathscr { O } _XOY→φ∗OX\mathscr { O } _Y \to \varphi _* \mathscr { O } _XOY​→φ∗​OX​.
A scheme is a locally ringed space with an open covering on which the space is isomorphic to affine schemes.

frontmatter.title: Value of section at a point

mainmatter.p: Given a locally ringed space and a section f \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )f∈Γ(U,O)f \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )f∈Γ(U,O), the germ of ffff at a point is an element of a local ring. The image of this element in the residue field, i.e. the quotient by the unique maximal ideal is called the value of this section at this point.

Given a ringed space, i.e. a space XXXX with a sheaf of rings \mathscr { O }O\mathscr { O }O, it is said to be locally ringed iff the following conditions hold: If \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } ) = 0Γ(U,O)=0\Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } ) = 0Γ(U,O)=0, then UUUU is empty. Suppose f + g \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )f+g∈Γ(U,O)f + g \in \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )f+g∈Γ(U,O) is invertible, then we can cover UUUU with two open sets such that ffff and gggg are invertible when restricted respectively. This can be unified as one condition: If a finite sum in \Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )Γ(U,O)\Gamma (U, \mathscr { O } )Γ(U,O) is invertible, then each summand is invertible when restricted to an open, which jointly covers UUUU.
A ringed space is a space equipped with a sheaf of rings, called the structure sheaf.

frontmatter.title: Sheaf and stalk from RRRR-modules

mainmatter.p: The proofs in and do not make use of the multiplication on the numerators. Therefore they immediately generalizes to modules. In particular, we have a sheaf corresponding to an RRRR-module MMMM, whose sections over D(f)D(f)D(f)D(f) form the R[f^{-1}]R[f−1]R[f^{-1}]R[f−1]-module M[f^{-1}]M[f−1]M[f^{-1}]M[f−1]. The stalk on \left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p]\left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p] is isomorphic to M_{ \left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ] }M[p]M_{ \left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ] }M[p]​.

mainmatter.p: Given a point \left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ] \in \operatorname {Spec} (R)[p]∈Spec⁡(R)\left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ] \in \operatorname {Spec} (R)[p]∈Spec(R), the stalk at the point is the localization R_{ \mathfrak { p } }RpR_{ \mathfrak { p } }Rp​. In particular, the ring spectrum is a locally ringed space by .

We take a directed limit. The elements are from some R[f^{-1}]R[f−1]R[f^{-1}]R[f−1] with \mathfrak { p } \nmid fp∤f\mathfrak { p } \nmid fp∤f, i.e. the elements can be written as g/f^ng/fng/f^ng/fn. Two elements are equal iff their common restriction to some D(f)D(f)D(f)D(f) is equal, i.e. g_1/f_1^n = g_2/f_2^mg1/f1n=g2/f2mg_1/f_1^n = g_2/f_2^mg1​/f1n​=g2​/f2m​ iff (g_1 f_2^m - g_2 f_1^n) f^k = 0(g1f2m−g2f1n)fk=0(g_1 f_2^m - g_2 f_1^n) f^k = 0(g1​f2m​−g2​f1n​)fk=0. These are exactly the definition of the localization away from \mathfrak { p }p\mathfrak { p }p.

frontmatter.title: Stalks of locally ringed topological space

mainmatter.p: Given a ringed topological space, it is locally ringed iff every stalk is a local ring.

Recall the axiom for a local ring: if any sum is invertible, then one of the summand is invertible. When applied to the direct limit in each stalk, this immediately expands to the definition of a locally ringed space.

In particular, a crucial property is used in the reverse implication, i.e. if one open contains all the points of another, then the former covers the latter. This is equivalent to the condition of having enough points.

frontmatter.title: Irreducible closeds in a ring spectrum

mainmatter.p: A closed V( \mathfrak { r } )V(r)V( \mathfrak { r } )V(r) in \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R) is irreducible iff \mathfrak { r }r\mathfrak { r }r is prime, and it is an irreducible component iff \mathfrak { r }r\mathfrak { r }r is a minimal prime ideal, i.e. prime ideals that divide no other prime ideals.

Translating via , we have a proper ideal \mathfrak { r }r\mathfrak { r }r that cannot be written as \operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { r } _1, \mathfrak { r } _2)lcm⁡(r1,r2)\operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { r } _1, \mathfrak { r } _2)lcm(r1​,r2​) non-trivially. Suppose \mathfrak { r } \mid f gr∣fg\mathfrak { r } \mid f gr∣fg, then \mathfrak { r } \mid \sqrt {f g} \mid \operatorname {lcm} (f, g)r∣fg∣lcm⁡(f,g)\mathfrak { r } \mid \sqrt {f g} \mid \operatorname {lcm} (f, g)r∣fg​∣lcm(f,g). So \begin {aligned} \mathfrak { r } &= \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , \operatorname {lcm} (f, g)) \\ &= \operatorname {lcm} ( \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , f), \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , g)). \end {aligned}r=gcd⁡(r,lcm⁡(f,g))=lcm⁡(gcd⁡(r,f),gcd⁡(r,g)).\begin {aligned} \mathfrak { r } &= \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , \operatorname {lcm} (f, g)) \\ &= \operatorname {lcm} ( \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , f), \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , g)). \end {aligned}r​=gcd(r,lcm(f,g))=lcm(gcd(r,f),gcd(r,g)).​ Hence at least one of the two must be equal to \mathfrak { r }r\mathfrak { r }r. So \mathfrak { r } \mid fr∣f\mathfrak { r } \mid fr∣f or \mathfrak { r } \mid gr∣g\mathfrak { r } \mid gr∣g.
An irreducible closed is an irreducible component if it is contained in no other irreducible closed. We immediately get the definition of minimal prime ideals translating to the algebraic realm.

The spectrum of a noetherian ring is always noetherian: the closeds corresponds to radical ideals. The converse does not hold. Consider a polynomial ring with infinitely many indeterminates x_1, x_2, \dotsx1,x2,…x_1, x_2, \dotsx1​,x2​,… quotiented by the relations x_k^k = 0xkk=0x_k^k = 0xkk​=0. The ideals in the quotient ring correspond to ideals in the polynomial ring dividing x_k^kxkkx_k^kxkk​ for every kkkk. So there are only two radical ideals: the trivial one, and the one that divides all indeterminates, but not constants. Hence the spectrum must be a noetherian space, but the ring is obviously not noetherian since it is not finitely generated itself.

frontmatter.title: Structure sheaf of a ring spectrum

mainmatter.p: Given a commutative ring RRRR, we define a sheaf \mathscr { O }O\mathscr { O }O of rings on \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R) called the structure sheaf. Let \Gamma (D(f), \mathscr { O } ) = R[f^{-1}]Γ(D(f),O)=R[f−1]\Gamma (D(f), \mathscr { O } ) = R[f^{-1}]Γ(D(f),O)=R[f−1]. Suppose D(f) \subseteq D(g)D(f)⊆D(g)D(f) \subseteq D(g)D(f)⊆D(g) we define the restriction morphism to be the localization map R[g^{-1}] \to R[f^{-1}]R[g−1]→R[f−1]R[g^{-1}] \to R[f^{-1}]R[g−1]→R[f−1], since by the latter is a further localization of the former. This turns \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R) into a ringed space.

We just need to verify the sheaf axioms on the bases, i.e. given a family of elements f_i \in Rfi∈Rf_i \in Rfi​∈R such that \bigcup _i D(f_i) = D(f)⋃iD(fi)=D(f)\bigcup _i D(f_i) = D(f)⋃i​D(fi​)=D(f), we need to show that R[f^{-1}] \to \prod _{i \in I} R[f_i^{-1}] \rightrightarrows \prod _{i \ne j} R[(f_i f_j)^{-1}]R[f−1]→∏i∈IR[fi−1]⇉∏i≠jR[(fifj)−1]R[f^{-1}] \to \prod _{i \in I} R[f_i^{-1}] \rightrightarrows \prod _{i \ne j} R[(f_i f_j)^{-1}]R[f−1]→i∈I∏​R[fi−1​]⇉i=j∏​R[(fi​fj​)−1] is an equalizer. Notice that R[f_i^{-1}] \cong R[f^{-1}][f_i^{-1}]R[fi−1]≅R[f−1][fi−1]R[f_i^{-1}] \cong R[f^{-1}][f_i^{-1}]R[fi−1​]≅R[f−1][fi−1​]. So we may reassign S = R[f^{-1}]S=R[f−1]S = R[f^{-1}]S=R[f−1]. This simplifies the problem to S \to \prod _{i \in I} S[f_i^{-1}] \rightrightarrows \prod _{i \ne j} S[(f_i f_j)^{-1}],S→∏i∈IS[fi−1]⇉∏i≠jS[(fifj)−1],S \to \prod _{i \in I} S[f_i^{-1}] \rightrightarrows \prod _{i \ne j} S[(f_i f_j)^{-1}],S→i∈I∏​S[fi−1​]⇉i=j∏​S[(fi​fj​)−1], where D(f_i)D(fi)D(f_i)D(fi​) covers the whole space \operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec⁡(S)\operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec(S).

We first describe the intuition. Since we know \operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec⁡(S)\operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec(S) is quasi-compact, we can roughly expect to reduce the problem to finite cases. Localization is a bit complicated due to zero-divisors, but suppose we don’t have them, we have elements g_i/f_i^{d_i} \in S[f_i^{-1}]gi/fidi∈S[fi−1]g_i/f_i^{d_i} \in S[f_i^{-1}]gi​/fidi​​∈S[fi−1​] that are equal in their common domain. Since D(f_i) = D(f_i^{d_i})D(fi)=D(fidi)D(f_i) = D(f_i^{d_i})D(fi​)=D(fidi​​) covers \operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec⁡(S)\operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec(S), we have a linear combination 1 = \sum _i c_i f_i^{d_i}1=∑icifidi1 = \sum _i c_i f_i^{d_i}1=∑i​ci​fidi​​, which is akin to a partition of unity. Suppose the putative gluing is ffff, multiplying with the partition of unity we get \begin {aligned} f &= \sum _{i \in I} c_i f_i^{d_i} f \\ &= \sum c_i f_i^{d_i} \frac {g_i}{f_i^{d_i}} \\ &= \sum c_i g_i. \end {aligned}f=∑i∈Icifidif=∑cifidigifidi=∑cigi.\begin {aligned} f &= \sum _{i \in I} c_i f_i^{d_i} f \\ &= \sum c_i f_i^{d_i} \frac {g_i}{f_i^{d_i}} \\ &= \sum c_i g_i. \end {aligned}f​=i∈I∑​ci​fidi​​f=∑ci​fidi​​fidi​​gi​​=∑ci​gi​.​ which defines the gluing. Hence f = \sum _{i \in I} c_i f f_i^R = \sum c_i g_i f_i^{R-d}.f=∑i∈IciffiR=∑cigifiR−d.f = \sum _{i \in I} c_i f f_i^R = \sum c_i g_i f_i^{R-d}.f=i∈I∑​ci​ffiR​=∑ci​gi​fiR−d​. This uniquely determines ffff. And indeed, this solution satisfies our requirements, because when restricted to D(f_j)D(fj)D(f_j)D(fj​), we have \begin {aligned} f f_j^d \cdot f_j^R &= \sum c_i g_i f_i^{R-d} f_j^{R+d} \\ &= \sum c_i g_j f_i^{R} f_j^{R} \\ &= g_j f_j^R \cdot \sum c_i f_i^R = g_j f_j^R. \end {aligned}ffjd⋅fjR=∑cigifiR−dfjR+d=∑cigjfiRfjR=gjfjR⋅∑cifiR=gjfjR.\begin {aligned} f f_j^d \cdot f_j^R &= \sum c_i g_i f_i^{R-d} f_j^{R+d} \\ &= \sum c_i g_j f_i^{R} f_j^{R} \\ &= g_j f_j^R \cdot \sum c_i f_i^R = g_j f_j^R. \end {aligned}ffjd​⋅fjR​​=∑ci​gi​fiR−d​fjR+d​=∑ci​gj​fiR​fjR​=gj​fjR​⋅∑ci​fiR​=gj​fjR​.​ This reasoning is valid as long as R > N + 2dR>N+2dR > N + 2dR>N+2d.

If there are infinitely many opens, we first use quasi-compactness to select a finite number D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k)D(f1),…,D(fk)D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k)D(f1​),…,D(fk​) that covers the whole space. The uniqueness of gluing solutions in the finite case implies that of the infinite case. For existence, first take the solution ffff for D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k)D(f1),…,D(fk)D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k)D(f1​),…,D(fk​). Then consider the solution on D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k) , D(g)D(f1),…,D(fk),D(g)D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k) , D(g)D(f1​),…,D(fk​),D(g) for every gggg. This solution must be equal to ffff by uniqueness. Therefore ffff restrict to the correct function on each D(g)D(g)D(g)D(g), showing that ffff is the required solution.
I try to adhere to several principles when composing trees.

ul.li: If a part of a proof has an easy constructive phrasing, use it and avoid classical reasoning. But if it requires some complication, then the classical way is used.

Avoid abstraction leaks. Even if A is defined as B, do not use them interchangeably. For instance, an ideal is defined as a subset of a ring satisfying certain conditions. But we will insist on writing ideals as numbers, for example saying \mathfrak { a } \mid xa∣x\mathfrak { a } \mid xa∣x instead of x \in \mathfrak { a }x∈ax \in \mathfrak { a }x∈a. This is not too heretic, since algebraic number theory already uses this kind of notation. Similarly, although prime ideals corresponds to points in \operatorname {Spec} (A)Spec⁡(A)\operatorname {Spec} (A)Spec(A), we do not identify them.
Apply unbiased terminology and negative thinking.

frontmatter.title: \operatorname {Spec} {R}Spec⁡R\operatorname {Spec} {R}SpecR is disconnected iff RRRR is a product of non-zero rings

mainmatter.p: Given a commutative ring RRRR, \operatorname {Spec} {R}Spec⁡R\operatorname {Spec} {R}SpecR is disconnected iff R \cong R_1 \times R_2R≅R1×R2R \cong R_1 \times R_2R≅R1​×R2​, where R_1, R_2R1,R2R_1, R_2R1​,R2​ are non-zero commutative rings.

In one direction, if \operatorname {Spec} {R}Spec⁡R\operatorname {Spec} {R}SpecR is disconnected, we have two opens D( \mathfrak { a } )D(a)D( \mathfrak { a } )D(a) and D( \mathfrak { b } )D(b)D( \mathfrak { b } )D(b) whose intersection is empty and union is the entire space. In other words radical ideals \mathfrak { a } , \mathfrak { b }a,b\mathfrak { a } , \mathfrak { b }a,b such that \sqrt { \gcd ( \mathfrak { a } , \mathfrak { b } )} = 1gcd⁡(a,b)=1\sqrt { \gcd ( \mathfrak { a } , \mathfrak { b } )} = 1gcd(a,b)​=1 (equivalent to \gcd ( \mathfrak { a } , \mathfrak { b } ) = 1gcd⁡(a,b)=1\gcd ( \mathfrak { a } , \mathfrak { b } ) = 1gcd(a,b)=1) and \operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { a } , \mathfrak { b } ) = 0lcm⁡(a,b)=0\operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { a } , \mathfrak { b } ) = 0lcm(a,b)=0. We have \mathfrak { a } \mid aa∣a\mathfrak { a } \mid aa∣a and \mathfrak { b } \mid bb∣b\mathfrak { b } \mid bb∣b such that a + b = 1a+b=1a + b = 1a+b=1. But \operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { a } , \mathfrak { b } ) \mid a blcm⁡(a,b)∣ab\operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { a } , \mathfrak { b } ) \mid a blcm(a,b)∣ab, therefore a b = 0ab=0a b = 0ab=0. This implies a(1-a) = 0a(1−a)=0a(1-a) = 0a(1−a)=0, or a^2 = aa2=aa^2 = aa2=a. The same goes for bbbb.

Let R_1R1R_1R1​ be the subset of RRRR consisting of multiples of aaaa. It contains an identity aaaa, since a \cdot a x = a xa⋅ax=axa \cdot a x = a xa⋅ax=ax by idempotence. Hence this subset forms a ring with the same addition and multiplication but a different identity. The same goes for R_2R2R_2R2​, the multiples of bbbb. There is an obvious map R_1 \times R_2 \to RR1×R2→RR_1 \times R_2 \to RR1​×R2​→R, given by (ax, by) \mapsto ax + by(ax,by)↦ax+by(ax, by) \mapsto ax + by(ax,by)↦ax+by. This is an injection since z \mapsto a zz↦azz \mapsto a zz↦az recovers the first argument, and z \mapsto b zz↦bzz \mapsto b zz↦bz recovers the second. It is also a surjection because z = a z + b zz=az+bzz = a z + b zz=az+bz is the image of (az, bz)(az,bz)(az, bz)(az,bz). Hence we found an isomorphism.

In the other direction, suppose R \cong R_1 \times R_2R≅R1×R2R \cong R_1 \times R_2R≅R1​×R2​, then D((1,0))D((1,0))D((1,0))D((1,0)) and D((0,1))D((0,1))D((0,1))D((0,1)) separates the spectrum into two disjoint parts.
If a commutative ring RRRR is noetherian, then R[x]R[x]R[x]R[x] is also noetherian.

Being noetherian is equivalent to having all ideals finitely generated. Suppose we have an ideal \mathfrak { a } R \subseteq RaR⊆R\mathfrak { a } R \subseteq RaR⊆R. We recursively produce a list of generators. Suppose we have already selected f_1, \dots , f_nf1,…,fnf_1, \dots , f_nf1​,…,fn​. If this doesn’t generate \mathfrak { a } RaR\mathfrak { a } RaR, then we select another one of the lowest degree. We prove that this procedure terminates.

Consider the initial coefficient c_icic_ici​ of f_ifif_ifi​. The ideal \mathfrak { c } _kck\mathfrak { c } _kck​ generated by the first kkkk elements must eventually stabilize. Let’s say c_{n+1} = \sum _{i=1}^n b_i c_icn+1=∑i=1nbicic_{n+1} = \sum _{i=1}^n b_i c_icn+1​=∑i=1n​bi​ci​. Then we can subtract f_{n+1}fn+1f_{n+1}fn+1​ by suitable multiples of f_1, \dots , f_nf1,…,fnf_1, \dots , f_nf1​,…,fn​ to cancel the leading term. This must not belong to ideal generated by f_1, \dots , f_nf1,…,fnf_1, \dots , f_nf1​,…,fn​, which contradicts our choice of generators, being of the lowest degree.
The space \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R) is always quasi-compact.

Since quasi-compectness can be tested on a basis, we just have to show that if \bigcup _i D(f_i) = \top⋃iD(fi)=⊤\bigcup _i D(f_i) = \top⋃i​D(fi​)=⊤, then there is a finite union equal to \top⊤\top⊤. Algebraically this means \sqrt { \gcd \{ f_i \} } = 1gcd⁡{fi}=1\sqrt { \gcd \{ f_i \} } = 1gcd{fi​}​=1, equivalently \gcd \{ f_i \} = 1gcd⁡{fi}=1\gcd \{ f_i \} = 1gcd{fi​}=1. So we have a linear combination \sum _k a_k f_k = 1∑kakfk=1\sum _k a_k f_k = 1∑k​ak​fk​=1. Crucially, this can only be a finite combination. Hence we can take the non-zero terms, whose corresponding opens already cover the whole space.

frontmatter.title: A closed in a noetherian space is uniquely a finite union of irreducible closeds

mainmatter.p: If XXXX is a noetherian space, then a closed Z \subseteq XZ⊆XZ \subseteq XZ⊆X can be written uniquely as the union of finitely many irreducible closeds.

We first deal with existence. By noetherianness, we perform well-founded induction. Suppose all the closed subsets of ZZZZ can be written as a finite union. If ZZZZ is irreducible then we’re done. Otherwise Z = Z_1 \cup Z_2Z=Z1∪Z2Z = Z_1 \cup Z_2Z=Z1​∪Z2​ is a non-trivial union of two closeds. By the induction hypothesis Z_1Z1Z_1Z1​ and Z_2Z2Z_2Z2​ can be written as a finite union of irreducible closeds, which we can combine to get the desired union.

We then prove uniqueness. Suppose Z_1 \cup \cdots \cup Z_n = Z'_1 \cup \cdots \cup Z'_m.Z1∪⋯∪Zn=Z1′∪⋯∪Zm′.Z_1 \cup \cdots \cup Z_n = Z'_1 \cup \cdots \cup Z'_m.Z1​∪⋯∪Zn​=Z1′​∪⋯∪Zm′​. Consider the intersection with Z_1Z1Z_1Z1​. The left hand side collapses to Z_1Z1Z_1Z1​. The right hand side becomes \bigcup _{i=1}^m (Z'_i \cap Z_1)⋃i=1m(Zi′∩Z1)\bigcup _{i=1}^m (Z'_i \cap Z_1)⋃i=1m​(Zi′​∩Z1​). Since Z_1Z1Z_1Z1​ is irreducible, Z'_i \cap Z_1Zi′∩Z1Z'_i \cap Z_1Zi′​∩Z1​ must be either Z_1Z1Z_1Z1​ or empty. In the former case, since Z'_iZi′Z'_iZi′​ is also irreducible, Z'_i = Z_1Zi′=Z1Z'_i = Z_1Zi′​=Z1​. Therefore each Z_jZjZ_jZj​ appears in the right hand side, and vice versa. Therefore the two sides are the same up to reordering and repetition.

frontmatter.title: Characterization of the locale \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R)

mainmatter.p: The opens in the locale \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R) bijectively corresponds to radical ideals of RRRR, whose divisibility relation agree with the inverse inclusion relation of opens. Intersections correspond to lowest common multiple, and unions correspond to the radical of the greatest common divisor. In other words, the locale is isomorphic to the locale corresponding to the topological spectrum of a commutative ring by .

We can first put the opens in disjunctive normal form U = \bigcup _{i \in I} \bigcap _{j=1}^{n_i} D(f_{i, j}).U=⋃i∈I⋂j=1niD(fi,j).U = \bigcup _{i \in I} \bigcap _{j=1}^{n_i} D(f_{i, j}).U=i∈I⋃​j=1⋂ni​​D(fi,j​). By the definition we can reduce the intersections into products. Write f_i = \prod _j f_{i, j}fi=∏jfi,jf_i = \prod _j f_{i, j}fi​=∏j​fi,j​, we have U = \bigcup _i D(f_i)U=⋃iD(fi)U = \bigcup _i D(f_i)U=⋃i​D(fi​). Given this form, we can try to saturate the union, by throwing in everything that doesn’t enlarge UUUU. In other words, we only consider the unions such that no other generator D(f)D(f)D(f)D(f) can be added, i.e. D(f) \nsubseteq UD(f)⊈UD(f) \nsubseteq UD(f)⊈U. This would uniquely determine UUUU.

Such a saturated set would have to be closed under addition since D(f+g) \subseteq D(f) \cup D(g)D(f+g)⊆D(f)∪D(g)D(f+g) \subseteq D(f) \cup D(g)D(f+g)⊆D(f)∪D(g), and for the nullary case it must include D(0) = \botD(0)=⊥D(0) = \botD(0)=⊥. It also has to absorb multiplication, because D(f \cdot g) \subseteq D(f)D(f⋅g)⊆D(f)D(f \cdot g) \subseteq D(f)D(f⋅g)⊆D(f). This means we are dealing with ideals. Henceforth, we write D( \mathfrak { a } )D(a)D( \mathfrak { a } )D(a) for the union \bigcup _{ \mathfrak { a } \mid f} D(f)⋃a∣fD(f)\bigcup _{ \mathfrak { a } \mid f} D(f)⋃a∣f​D(f).

There is one last requirement we haven’t dealt with, i.e. D(f \cdot g)D(f⋅g)D(f \cdot g)D(f⋅g) is the greatest lower bound of D(f)D(f)D(f)D(f) and D(g)D(g)D(g)D(g), instead of simply a lower bound. For example, this gives the equality D(f^n) = D(f)D(fn)=D(f)D(f^n) = D(f)D(fn)=D(f), so we need to restrict our attention to radical ideals. It then suffices to prove that the radical ideal generated by f \cdot gf⋅gf \cdot gf⋅g is equal to the lowest common multiple of the radical ideals generated by ffff and gggg, which is true.

frontmatter.title: Localic spectrum of a commutative ring

mainmatter.p: To define functions on an “algebraic space”, we need to define the possible domains. The correct structure formed by the domains is a locale. Intuitively, the only algebraic way for a function to become partially defined is by having zero in the denominator f/gf/gf/gf/g, so the domain should be the non-vanishing part of gggg, which we denote as D(g)D(g)D(g)D(g).

frontmatter.title: Rational functions not definable via a single expression

mainmatter.p: We can sometimes define two functions that agree on their common domain, which suggests we should be able to piece them together into a larger function. But this may not always be expressible with one single expression.

For example, on the space given by xy = zwxy=zwxy = zwxy=zw, we can define a funtion given by x/wx/wx/wx/w, which is equal to z/yz/yz/yz/y. They are only jointly undefined on w = z = 0w=z=0w = z = 0w=z=0, but there is no single expression that achieves this.
Recognizing this, we can try to freely generate a locale using D(g)D(g)D(g)D(g) as generators. We would like some obvious relations corresponding to each algebraic operation in the ring.

We can actually produce a characterization of these generated opens. The following theorem is best read by skipping the statement and jump right into the proof, allowing the correct statement to gradually reveal itself.
