A space is noetherian if every descending chain of closeds, or equivalently every ascending chain of opens stabilizes. In other words, the partial order of closeds is well-founded.

frontmatter.title: Rational functions not definable via a single expression

mainmatter.p: We can sometimes define two functions that agree on their common domain, which suggests we should be able to piece them together into a larger function. But this may not always be expressible with one single expression.

For example, on the space given by xy = zwxy=zwxy = zwxy=zw, we can define a funtion given by x/wx/wx/wx/w, which is equal to z/yz/yz/yz/y. They are only jointly undefined on w = z = 0w=z=0w = z = 0w=z=0, but there is no single expression that achieves this.

frontmatter.title: Terminology of compactness in algebraic geometry

mainmatter.p: The word compactness historically required the space to be Hausdorff. And the modern meaning of compactness was called quasi-compact. In algebraic geometry, most spaces are never Hausdorff, and the topological compactness condition does not lead to similar behavior. There is another notion more suitable as an analog of topological compactness. Therefore, we choose to always use the word “quasi-compact”.

frontmatter.title: The radical ideal is the lcm of prime ideal divisors

mainmatter.p: For any ideal \mathfrak { a }a\mathfrak { a }a of a commutative ring, the radical \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }a\sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }a​ is the lowest common multiple of the prime ideals \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a.

On one hand, if \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid fa∣f\sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid fa​∣f, then \mathfrak { a } \mid f^na∣fn\mathfrak { a } \mid f^na∣fn for some natural number nnnn. This means for all \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a, we have \mathfrak { p } \mid f^np∣fn\mathfrak { p } \mid f^np∣fn, which by being a prime ideal implies \mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f\mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f.

frontmatter.title: Radical ideals bijectively correspond to open sets

mainmatter.p: In an arbitrary topological spectrum of a commutative ring, we have D( \mathfrak { a } ) = D( \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } })D(a)=D(a)D( \mathfrak { a } ) = D( \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } })D(a)=D(a​). There is a containment of opens D( \mathfrak { a } ) \subseteq D( \mathfrak { b } )D(a)⊆D(b)D( \mathfrak { a } ) \subseteq D( \mathfrak { b } )D(a)⊆D(b) — equivalently V( \mathfrak { b } ) \subseteq V( \mathfrak { a } )V(b)⊆V(a)V( \mathfrak { b } ) \subseteq V( \mathfrak { a } )V(b)⊆V(a) — iff \sqrt { \mathfrak { b } } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }b∣a\sqrt { \mathfrak { b } } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }b​∣a​, and the points contained in an open set completely determines the radical ideal.

Since \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a implies \sqrt { \mathfrak { p } } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }p∣a\sqrt { \mathfrak { p } } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }p​∣a​, but \mathfrak { p } = \sqrt { \mathfrak { p } }p=p\mathfrak { p } = \sqrt { \mathfrak { p } }p=p​, we see that D( \mathfrak { a } ) = D( \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } })D(a)=D(a)D( \mathfrak { a } ) = D( \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } })D(a)=D(a​). We just have to prove the forward implication of the last statement. Suppose for all prime ideals \mathfrak { p }p\mathfrak { p }p we have \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { b } \implies \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣b  ⟹  p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { b } \implies \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣b⟹p∣a. We need to prove that \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid f \implies \sqrt { \mathfrak { b } } \mid fa∣f  ⟹  b∣f\sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid f \implies \sqrt { \mathfrak { b } } \mid fa​∣f⟹b​∣f.

Given \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid fa∣f\sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid fa​∣f, we have \mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f\mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f for all prime ideals \mathfrak { p } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }p∣a​ (which is equivalent to \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a). So we know that for all \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { b }p∣b\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { b }p∣b, \mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f\mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f. This is now purely a condition on \mathfrak { b }b\mathfrak { b }b. The next lemma finishes the proof.

frontmatter.title: The radical ideal is the lcm of prime ideal divisors

mainmatter.p: For any ideal \mathfrak { a }a\mathfrak { a }a of a commutative ring, the radical \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }a\sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }a​ is the lowest common multiple of the prime ideals \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a.

On one hand, if \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid fa∣f\sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid fa​∣f, then \mathfrak { a } \mid f^na∣fn\mathfrak { a } \mid f^na∣fn for some natural number nnnn. This means for all \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a, we have \mathfrak { p } \mid f^np∣fn\mathfrak { p } \mid f^np∣fn, which by being a prime ideal implies \mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f\mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f.

frontmatter.title: Topological spectrum of a commutative ring

mainmatter.p: The topological spectrum of a commutative ring RRRR, denoted \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R), is a topological space whose points are given by prime ideals of RRRR. We denote the point corresponding to \mathfrak { p }p\mathfrak { p }p as \left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p]\left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p]. We define an open D( \mathfrak { a } )D(a)D( \mathfrak { a } )D(a) for each ideal \mathfrak { a }a\mathfrak { a }a which contains the point \left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p]\left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p] when \mathfrak { p } \nmid \mathfrak { a }p∤a\mathfrak { p } \nmid \mathfrak { a }p∤a. The corresponding closed is written as V( \mathfrak { a } )V(a)V( \mathfrak { a } )V(a).
We abuse the notation and write D(f)D(f)D(f)D(f) for the case where \mathfrak { a }a\mathfrak { a }a is generated by ffff. Similar notations apply to VVVV.

Given a mathematical object XXXX canonically associated with an effective chain complex C_ \bullet (X)C∙(X)C_ \bullet (X)C∙​(X) (e.g. the normalized chain complex of a simplicial set), it is said to be equipped with the structure of effective homology, if we have a strong homology equivalence C_ \bullet (X) \Leftarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Leftrightarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Rightarrow E_ \bulletC∙(X)⇐⇔⇒E∙C_ \bullet (X) \Leftarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Leftrightarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Rightarrow E_ \bulletC∙​(X)⇐⇔⇒E∙​, such that E_ \bulletE∙E_ \bulletE∙​ is effective of finite type.
This is a set of notes on effective homology and algebraic topology. Main references are Constructive Homological Algebra and Applications and ...
TODO: composition of strong homology equivalence, tensor product, cone, bicomplex, (effective) simplicial set, simplicial group, Kan complex

A strong homology equivalence between chain complexes CCCC and DDDD is a span of chain reductions, i.e. a third chain complex XXXX with X \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow CX⇒⇒CX \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow CX⇒⇒C and X \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow DX⇒⇒DX \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow DX⇒⇒D. We denote a strong homology equivalence with C \Leftarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Leftrightarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Rightarrow DC⇐⇔⇒DC \Leftarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Leftrightarrow \mkern {-13mu} \Rightarrow DC⇐⇔⇒D.

frontmatter.title: Perturbation of the larger chain complex in a chain reduction

mainmatter.p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D and a perturbation \delta _CδC\delta _CδC​ for CCCC, we assume that h_{ \rho } \circ \delta _Chρ∘δCh_{ \rho } \circ \delta _Chρ​∘δC​ is pointwise nilpotent, i.e. \forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb {N}, \; ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^n (c) = 0.∀c∈Ck,∃n∈N,  (hρδC)n(c)=0.\forall c \in C_k, \exists n \in \mathbb {N}, \; ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^n (c) = 0.∀c∈Ck​,∃n∈N,(hρ​δC​)n(c)=0. We can construct a new chain reduction \rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D'ρ′:C′⇒⇒D′\rho ' : C' \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow D'ρ′:C′⇒⇒D′, where C'C′C'C′ is CCCC perturbed by \delta _CδC\delta _CδC​.
Note that this situation is much harder compared to , as it is generally impossible without the added condition.

For this construction using the third equivalent definition of a chain reduction in , i.e. a homotopy operator on CCCC such that h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0 and h \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC∘h=hh \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC​∘h=h.

We need to construct a new homotopy operator such that h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0 and h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' = h'h′∘(dC+δC)∘h′=h′h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' = h'h′∘(dC​+δC​)∘h′=h′. We approach this through a “perturbative” mindset. Starting with h_0 = hh0=hh_0 = hh0​=h, the second equation is off by a difference of h_0 \delta _C h_0h0δCh0h_0 \delta _C h_0h0​δC​h0​. We simply add this as a correction term, h_1 = h_0 + \alpha h_0 \delta _C h_0h1=h0+αh0δCh0h_1 = h_0 + \alpha h_0 \delta _C h_0h1​=h0​+αh0​δC​h0​ where \alphaα\alphaα is some coefficient. (Note that essentially the only terms we can consider are of the form h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C \cdots h_0h0δCh0δC⋯h0h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C \cdots h_0h0​δC​h0​δC​⋯h0​, since nothing else has the same type.) We still have h_1 \circ h_1 = 0h1∘h1=0h_1 \circ h_1 = 0h1​∘h1​=0, and for the second equation this creates a new error term \begin {aligned} & \quad h_1 (d_C + \delta _C) h_1 - h_1 \\ &= (1 + \alpha ) h_0 \delta _C h_0 + 2 ( \alpha + \alpha ^2) h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 + \alpha ^2 h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \end {aligned}h1(dC+δC)h1−h1=(1+α)h0δCh0+2(α+α2)h0δCh0δCh0+α2h0δCh0δCh0δCh0\begin {aligned} & \quad h_1 (d_C + \delta _C) h_1 - h_1 \\ &= (1 + \alpha ) h_0 \delta _C h_0 + 2 ( \alpha + \alpha ^2) h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 + \alpha ^2 h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0 \end {aligned}​h1​(dC​+δC​)h1​−h1​=(1+α)h0​δC​h0​+2(α+α2)h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​+α2h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​δC​h0​​ and we can eliminate the first and second order part by setting \alpha = -1α=−1\alpha = -1α=−1. The natural next step would be to add a further correction h_2 = h_1 + \beta h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0h2=h1+βh0δCh0δCh0h_2 = h_1 + \beta h_0 \delta _C h_0 \delta _C h_0h2​=h1​+βh0​δC​h0​δC​h0​. This turns out to require \beta = +1β=+1\beta = +1β=+1, and so on.

From the informal discussion above, we can conjecture the formula h' = \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h.h′=∑k=0∞(−1)k(hδC)kh.h' = \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h.h′=k=0∑∞​(−1)k(hδC​)kh. This reveals the reason for our pointwise nilpotency condition. With a little bit of care manipulating the infinite sum, we can prove that h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0h' \circ h' = 0h′∘h′=0 from h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0, and the second equation follows from a nice telescopic sum \begin {aligned} h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta _C)^i h (d_C + \delta _C) (h \delta _C)^j h \\ &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left [(h \delta _C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^{i + j} h \right ] \\ &= \sum _{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left [(h \delta _C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^k h \right ] \\ &= \sum _k (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h = h'. \end {aligned}h′∘(dC+δC)∘h′=∑i,j(−1)i+j(hδC)ih(dC+δC)(hδC)jh=∑i,j(−1)i+j[(hδC)i+j+1h+(hδC)i+jh]=∑k(k+1)(−1)k[(hδC)k+1h+(hδC)kh]=∑k(−1)k(hδC)kh=h′.\begin {aligned} h' \circ (d_C + \delta _C) \circ h' &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} (h \delta _C)^i h (d_C + \delta _C) (h \delta _C)^j h \\ &= \sum _{i, j} (-1)^{i + j} \left [(h \delta _C)^{i + j + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^{i + j} h \right ] \\ &= \sum _{k} (k+1) (-1)^k \left [(h \delta _C)^{k + 1} h + (h \delta _C)^k h \right ] \\ &= \sum _k (-1)^k (h \delta _C)^k h = h'. \end {aligned}h′∘(dC​+δC​)∘h′​=i,j∑​(−1)i+j(hδC​)ih(dC​+δC​)(hδC​)jh=i,j∑​(−1)i+j[(hδC​)i+j+1h+(hδC​)i+jh]=k∑​(k+1)(−1)k[(hδC​)k+1h+(hδC​)kh]=k∑​(−1)k(hδC​)kh=h′.​

We can reconstruct the other two components of the reduction \iota _{ \rho ' }ιρ′\iota _{ \rho ' }ιρ′​ and \pi _{ \rho ' }πρ′\pi _{ \rho ' }πρ′​ through . In particular, D'D′D'D′ is given by a perturbation of DDDD. We only write down the results below for easy reference. \begin {aligned} \pi _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } ( \delta _C h_{ \rho } )^k \\ \iota _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } \\ \delta _D &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } \delta _C ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } . \end {aligned}πρ′=∑k=0∞(−1)kπρ(δChρ)kιρ′=∑k=0∞(−1)k(hρδC)kιρδD=∑k=0∞(−1)kπρδC(hρδC)kιρ.\begin {aligned} \pi _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } ( \delta _C h_{ \rho } )^k \\ \iota _{ \rho ' } &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } \\ \delta _D &= \sum _{k=0}^ \infty (-1)^k \pi _{ \rho } \delta _C ( h_{ \rho } \delta _C)^k \iota _{ \rho } . \end {aligned}πρ′​ιρ′​δD​​=k=0∑∞​(−1)kπρ​(δC​hρ​)k=k=0∑∞​(−1)k(hρ​δC​)kιρ​=k=0∑∞​(−1)kπρ​δC​(hρ​δC​)kιρ​.​

The following data are equivalent: A chain reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D. A splitting C \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕EC \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕E, where EEEE is a split exact. A chain homotopy h : C \to Ch:C→Ch : C \to Ch:C→C satisfying h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0 and h \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC∘h=hh \circ d_C \circ h = hh∘dC​∘h=h.

A chain reduction consists of maps C_k \mathrel { \smash { \xtofrom [g_k]{f_k}}} D_kCk⇄gkfkDkC_k \mathrel { \smash { \xtofrom [g_k]{f_k}}} D_kCk​fk​gk​​Dk​ such that f_k \circ g_k = \operatorname {id}fk∘gk=id⁡f_k \circ g_k = \operatorname {id}fk​∘gk​=id. Therefore C_ \bulletC∙C_ \bulletC∙​ splits as D_ \bullet \oplus E_ \bulletD∙⊕E∙D_ \bullet \oplus E_ \bulletD∙​⊕E∙​, and the boundary maps are preserved since f, gf,gf, gf,g are chain maps. We have a homotopy h_k : D_k \oplus E_k \to D_{k+1} \oplus E_{k+1}hk:Dk⊕Ek→Dk+1⊕Ek+1h_k : D_k \oplus E_k \to D_{k+1} \oplus E_{k+1}hk​:Dk​⊕Ek​→Dk+1​⊕Ek+1​, which we may write as a (2 \times 2)(2×2)(2 \times 2)(2×2)-matrix. f \circ h = 0f∘h=0f \circ h = 0f∘h=0 demands the first row to be zero, and h \circ g = 0h∘g=0h \circ g = 0h∘g=0 requires the first column to vanish. This leaves us with \begin {bmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & r_k \end {bmatrix}[000rk]\begin {bmatrix} 0 & 0 \\ 0 & r_k \end {bmatrix}[00​0rk​​] such that r_{k+1} \circ r_k = 0rk+1∘rk=0r_{k+1} \circ r_k = 0rk+1​∘rk​=0, since h \circ h = 0h∘h=0h \circ h = 0h∘h=0.

Substituting the requirement that hhhh is a homotopy \operatorname {id} \to g \circ fid⁡→g∘f\operatorname {id} \to g \circ fid→g∘f, we get the equation d_{k+1} \circ r_k + r_{k-1} \circ d_k = \operatorname {id} ,dk+1∘rk+rk−1∘dk=id⁡,d_{k+1} \circ r_k + r_{k-1} \circ d_k = \operatorname {id} ,dk+1​∘rk​+rk−1​∘dk​=id, where dddd is the boundary operator on E_ \bulletE∙E_ \bulletE∙​. In other words, rrrr is a null-homotopy of E_ \bulletE∙E_ \bulletE∙​, rendering it split exact. Conversely, given C \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕EC \cong D \oplus EC≅D⊕E, we can reconstruct ffff and gggg as the projection and inclusion maps, with hhhh obtained out of rrrr in the manner depicted above.

On the other hand, given only the homotopy operator, we expect to have d \circ h + h \circ d = \operatorname {id} - g \circ fd∘h+h∘d=id⁡−g∘fd \circ h + h \circ d = \operatorname {id} - g \circ fd∘h+h∘d=id−g∘f. And since g \circ fg∘fg \circ fg∘f should be the projector of CCCC onto the subspace DDDD, \operatorname {id} - g \circ fid⁡−g∘f\operatorname {id} - g \circ fid−g∘f should be the projector onto EEEE. We are thus led to proving p = d \circ h + h \circ dp=d∘h+h∘dp = d \circ h + h \circ dp=d∘h+h∘d is indeed a projector. \begin {aligned} p_k \circ p_k &= (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \circ (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ d_{k+1} \circ h_k}^{h_k} + d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ h_{k-1}}^{0} \circ d_k \\ & \qquad + h_{k-1} \circ \underbrace {d_k \circ d_{k+1}}_{0} \circ h_k + \underbrace {h_{k-1} \circ d_k \circ h_{k-1}}_{h_{k-1}} \circ d_k \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k = p_k. \end {aligned}pk∘pk=(dk+1∘hk+hk−1∘dk)∘(dk+1∘hk+hk−1∘dk)=dk+1∘hk∘dk+1∘hk⏞hk+dk+1∘hk∘hk−1⏞0∘dk+hk−1∘dk∘dk+1⏟0∘hk+hk−1∘dk∘hk−1⏟hk−1∘dk=dk+1∘hk+hk−1∘dk=pk.\begin {aligned} p_k \circ p_k &= (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \circ (d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k) \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ d_{k+1} \circ h_k}^{h_k} + d_{k+1} \circ \overbrace {h_k \circ h_{k-1}}^{0} \circ d_k \\ & \qquad + h_{k-1} \circ \underbrace {d_k \circ d_{k+1}}_{0} \circ h_k + \underbrace {h_{k-1} \circ d_k \circ h_{k-1}}_{h_{k-1}} \circ d_k \\ &= d_{k+1} \circ h_k + h_{k-1} \circ d_k = p_k. \end {aligned}pk​∘pk​​=(dk+1​∘hk​+hk−1​∘dk​)∘(dk+1​∘hk​+hk−1​∘dk​)=dk+1​∘hk​∘dk+1​∘hk​​hk​​+dk+1​∘hk​∘hk−1​​0​∘dk​+hk−1​∘0dk​∘dk+1​​​∘hk​+hk−1​hk−1​∘dk​∘hk−1​​​∘dk​=dk+1​∘hk​+hk−1​∘dk​=pk​.​ Therefore we conclude that p_kpkp_kpk​ splits C_k \cong D_k \oplus E_kCk≅Dk⊕EkC_k \cong D_k \oplus E_kCk​≅Dk​⊕Ek​. More over, p \circ d = d \circ h \circ d = d \circ pp∘d=d∘h∘d=d∘pp \circ d = d \circ h \circ d = d \circ pp∘d=d∘h∘d=d∘p, meaning pppp is a chain map, and therefore the splitting is compatible with the boundary operator. Since h \circ p = p \circ h = h \circ d \circ h = hh∘p=p∘h=h∘d∘h=hh \circ p = p \circ h = h \circ d \circ h = hh∘p=p∘h=h∘d∘h=h, the homotopy is also compatible with the splitting, so we can restrict it onto E_kEkE_kEk​ to get a homotopy from \operatorname {id} _Eid⁡E\operatorname {id} _EidE​ to 0000.

Finally, restricting hhhh onto D_kDkD_kDk​ we see that it must be zero, since h( \operatorname {id} - p) = h - h \circ d \circ h = 0h(id⁡−p)=h−h∘d∘h=0h( \operatorname {id} - p) = h - h \circ d \circ h = 0h(id−p)=h−h∘d∘h=0. This means that all the information of hhhh can be reconstructed from the splitting, and thus all three sets of data are equivalent.

frontmatter.title: Perturbation of the smaller chain complex in a chain reduction

mainmatter.p: Given a reduction \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D and a perturbation \delta _DδD\delta _DδD​ for DDDD, we can construct a perturbation \delta _CδC\delta _CδC​ for CCCC, such that the same \rhoρ\rhoρ can serve as a reduction of the perturbed chain complexes.

Let the reduction \rhoρ\rhoρ be made out of the three maps \pi _{ \rho } : C \to Dπρ:C→D\pi _{ \rho } : C \to Dπρ​:C→D, \iota _{ \rho } : D \to Cιρ:D→C\iota _{ \rho } : D \to Cιρ​:D→C and h_{ \rho } : C \to Chρ:C→Ch_{ \rho } : C \to Chρ​:C→C. Then since CCCC splits as the direct sum of DDDD and an acyclic complex, we can simply copy over the perturbation, and leave the acyclic part untouched. This gives us the definition \delta _C = \iota _{ \rho } \circ \delta _D \circ \pi _{ \rho }δC=ιρ∘δD∘πρ\delta _C = \iota _{ \rho } \circ \delta _D \circ \pi _{ \rho }δC​=ιρ​∘δD​∘πρ​. A quick computation shows that \rhoρ\rhoρ is still a reduction of the perturbed chain complexes.

frontmatter.title: Terminology of effective algebraic cellular complex

mainmatter.p: The terminology chosen here differs from that in Kenzo. What we call effective is named locally effective; and what we call effective of finite type is named effective instead.

frontmatter.title: Geometric interpretation of algebraic cellular complex

mainmatter.p: An ACC can be viewed as the algebraic distillation of a chain complex. The generators in dimension nnnn are regarded as nnnn-cells. However, we only record a formal sum of the boundaries, and forget the exact configuration. Hence, ACC is a suitable middle ground for both geometric transformations and algebraic operations.
For ACCs, the effect of a perturbation is to “reconnect” the cells. But it may not create or delete cells, since the abelian groups are unchanged.
A perturbation of a chain complex with boundary operator dddd is an operator \deltaδ\deltaδ of degree (-1)(−1)(-1)(−1) such that d + \deltad+δd + \deltad+δ also forms a boundary operator.

Given an algebraic cellular complex, suppose we can encode the basis sets C_ \bulletC∙C_ \bulletC∙​ such that they have decidable equality, and the maps C_k \to \mathbb {Z}^{(C_{k-1})}Ck→Z(Ck−1)C_k \to \mathbb {Z}^{(C_{k-1})}Ck​→Z(Ck−1​) are computable, then we say the ACC is effective. Suppose further that C_ \bulletC∙C_ \bulletC∙​ are (computably) finite sets, then we say it is effective of finite type.

frontmatter.title: An additive functor is exact iff it preserves quasi-isomorphisms

mainmatter.p: Given an additive functor F : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→BF : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→B between abelian categories, it is exact iff it sends quasi-isomorphisms to quasi-isomorphisms.
Suppose an additive functor preserves quasi-isomorphisms. Since a chain complex is exact iff it is quasi-isomorphic to the zero complex, the functor must preserve exactness.

On the other hand, exact functors commute with homology functors. Therefore if f : C_ \bullet \to D_ \bulletf:C∙→D∙f : C_ \bullet \to D_ \bulletf:C∙​→D∙​ is a quasi-isomorphism, H_n (f)Hn(f)H_n (f)Hn​(f) are all isomorphisms. Therefore H_n (F(f)) = F(H_n(f))Hn(F(f))=F(Hn(f))H_n (F(f)) = F(H_n(f))Hn​(F(f))=F(Hn​(f)) is the functorial action on an isomorphism, which must also produce an isomorphism.

Given two chain complexes C_ \bulletC∙C_ \bulletC∙​ and D_ \bulletD∙D_ \bulletD∙​ with two chain maps f, g : C \to Df,g:C→Df, g : C \to Df,g:C→D between them, a chain homotopy from ffff to gggg is given by a family of maps h_n : C_n \to D_{n+1}hn:Cn→Dn+1h_n : C_n \to D_{n+1}hn​:Cn​→Dn+1​, such that d_{n+1} \circ h_n + h_{n-1} \circ d_n = f_n - g_n.dn+1∘hn+hn−1∘dn=fn−gn.d_{n+1} \circ h_n + h_{n-1} \circ d_n = f_n - g_n.dn+1​∘hn​+hn−1​∘dn​=fn​−gn​. Note that the two dddd’s denote the boundary map of different chain complexes.

The chain homotopy can be written as h : f \to gh:f→gh : f \to gh:f→g or as h : C \to Dh:C→Dh : C \to Dh:C→D. This causes no confusion, and the latter is convenient in situations where the maps f, gf,gf, gf,g matter less than their difference f - gf−gf - gf−g.

Given two chain complexes C, DC,DC, DC,D, a chain reduction consists of a chain map \pi : C \to Dπ:C→D\pi : C \to Dπ:C→D, a chain map \iota : D \to Cι:D→C\iota : D \to Cι:D→C and a chain homotopy h : \operatorname {id} \to g \circ fh:id⁡→g∘fh : \operatorname {id} \to g \circ fh:id→g∘f, such that \pi \circ \iota = \operatorname {id}π∘ι=id⁡\pi \circ \iota = \operatorname {id}π∘ι=id, and \pi \circ h = h \circ \iota = h \circ h = 0.π∘h=h∘ι=h∘h=0.\pi \circ h = h \circ \iota = h \circ h = 0.π∘h=h∘ι=h∘h=0. Here the compositions are understood to have the appropriate subscript so the degrees match.

We write the reduction as \rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D\rho : C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow Dρ:C⇒⇒D. The three components are denoted \pi _{ \rho } : C \to Dπρ:C→D\pi _{ \rho } : C \to Dπρ​:C→D, \iota _{ \rho } : D \to Cιρ:D→C\iota _{ \rho } : D \to Cιρ​:D→C and h_{ \rho } : C \to Chρ:C→Ch_{ \rho } : C \to Chρ​:C→C, respectively.

For a chain reduction C \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow DC⇒⇒DC \Rightarrow \mkern {-14mu} \Rightarrow DC⇒⇒D, DDDD is embedded as a subcomplex of CCCC. It is cleanly separated, indicating that it is split. The other part of CCCC is split exact, and so its homology component is drawn as empty, with the components separated.

mainmatter.p: An algebraic cellular complex (or ACC) is a chain complex of free abelian groups, with designated generators. The generators are called cells, and the boundary maps can be expressed using the generators as a basis, yielding the incidence matrices.

More precisely, we may define an ACC as a sequence of sets C_ \bulletC∙C_ \bulletC∙​, with a sequence of functions C_k \to \mathbb {Z}^{(C_{k-1})}Ck→Z(Ck−1)C_k \to \mathbb {Z}^{(C_{k-1})}Ck​→Z(Ck−1​), such that d^2 = 0d2=0d^2 = 0d2=0 is satisfied.

Combining and , we arrive at the following picture. Each family of colors corresponds to the filtration F_ \bullet C_nF∙CnF_ \bullet C_nF∙​Cn​ in one dimension, and the different shades corresponds to the degree in the filtration.

So the intersection is a triangle shape instead of a complete diamond grid. This corresponds to the requirement that the boundary map sends F_i C_jFiCjF_i C_jFi​Cj​ to F_i C_{j+1}FiCj+1F_i C_{j+1}Fi​Cj+1​.
We can visualize a filtered object F_1 A \subseteq F_2 A \subseteq F_3 A \subseteq AF1A⊆F2A⊆F3A⊆AF_1 A \subseteq F_2 A \subseteq F_3 A \subseteq AF1​A⊆F2​A⊆F3​A⊆A as nested rectangles.

mainmatter.p: The graded components of this filtration are the individual rectangular regions.

Given a short exact sequence of chain complexes 0 \to A_ \bullet \to B_ \bullet \to C_ \bullet \to 0,0→A∙→B∙→C∙→0,0 \to A_ \bullet \to B_ \bullet \to C_ \bullet \to 0,0→A∙​→B∙​→C∙​→0, there is a long exact sequence of homology groups \cdots \to H_{n+1}(C) \xrightarrow { \partial } H_n(A) \to H_n (B) \to H_n (C) \xrightarrow { \partial } H_{n-1} (A) \to \cdots⋯→Hn+1(C)→∂Hn(A)→Hn(B)→Hn(C)→∂Hn−1(A)→⋯\cdots \to H_{n+1}(C) \xrightarrow { \partial } H_n(A) \to H_n (B) \to H_n (C) \xrightarrow { \partial } H_{n-1} (A) \to \cdots⋯→Hn+1​(C)∂​Hn​(A)→Hn​(B)→Hn​(C)∂​Hn−1​(A)→⋯ The map \partial∂\partial∂ here is, after unpacking some quotients, simply the boundary map B_n \to B_{n-1}Bn→Bn−1B_n \to B_{n-1}Bn​→Bn−1​.
In an abelian category, given the middle two rows of the diagram

mainmatter.p: such that the rows are exact, we can take the kernels and cokernels, which forms a long exact sequence of blue arrows, 0 \to \ker i \to \ker f \to \ker g \to \ker h \xrightarrow { \partial } \operatorname {coker} f \to \operatorname {coker} g \to \operatorname {coker} h \to \operatorname {coker} j \to 00→ker⁡i→ker⁡f→ker⁡g→ker⁡h→∂coker⁡f→coker⁡g→coker⁡h→coker⁡j→00 \to \ker i \to \ker f \to \ker g \to \ker h \xrightarrow { \partial } \operatorname {coker} f \to \operatorname {coker} g \to \operatorname {coker} h \to \operatorname {coker} j \to 00→keri→kerf→kerg→kerh∂​cokerf→cokerg→cokerh→cokerj→0. In particular, if iiii is monic and jjjj is epic, this leads to a six-term exact sequence.
There are multiple ways to prove this claim. We can first prove it in categories of modules, and use the Freyd–Mitchell embedding. We can also use pseudo-elements to perform diagram chases.

frontmatter.title: Using the Freyd–Mitchell embedding to prove theorems

mainmatter.p: We use the snake lemma as an example to demonstrate how the embedding theorem works in practice. The main technique is to avoid dealing with large categories.

Suppose we have already proved the theorem in module categories. Given a snake lemma diagram in an arbitrary (locally small) abelian category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C, we take the smallest full subcategory closed under finite limits and colimits. This results in a small category \mathcal { D }D\mathcal { D }D, which we can embed in a module category R \text {-} \mathsf { Mod }R-ModR \text {-} \mathsf { Mod }R-Mod.

Now, the snake lemma in module categories implies that we have the required maps that forms an exact sequence. Since \mathcal { D }D\mathcal { D }D is a full abelian subcategory of R \text {-} \mathsf { Mod }R-ModR \text {-} \mathsf { Mod }R-Mod, these morphisms are contained in \mathcal { D }D\mathcal { D }D, and the sequence is still exact. And since \mathcal { D }D\mathcal { D }D is a full abelian subcategory of \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C, the sequence is again exact in \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C.

Abelian categories are one step further from additive categories. Similar to the situation of abelian groups or modules, every morphism f : X \to Yf:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y has four key components, the image, the kernel, the coimage X / \ker fX/ker⁡fX / \ker fX/kerf, and the cokernel Y / \operatorname {im} fY/im⁡fY / \operatorname {im} fY/imf. The image is always identical with the coimage, representing the core part of the homomorphism. The kernel perfectly measures the failure of injectivity, and the cokernel perfectly measures the failure of surjectivity. This is in stark constrast with general maps, where the failure of injectivity may be heterogeneous, and thus cannot be simply characterized.

Since many operations on abelian groups and RRRR-modules can be performed on chain complexes, we wish to axiomatize an abstract notion to encapsulate them all. This motivates the definition of additive and abelian categories. We can use the three examples mentioned above as the source for intuitions for abelian categories.

First, we wish to let the morphisms form abelian groups. This turns out to have a surprising impact on the structure of categories, the most important of which is the coincidence of finite products and coproducts.

frontmatter.title: \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched category

mainmatter.p: Given a category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C, an \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enrichment is given by abelian group structures on every hom-set, such that composition is linear in each argument. In other words, we have a homomorphism \hom (Y, Z) \otimes \hom (X, Y) \to \hom (X, Z)hom⁡(Y,Z)⊗hom⁡(X,Y)→hom⁡(X,Z)\hom (Y, Z) \otimes \hom (X, Y) \to \hom (X, Z)hom(Y,Z)⊗hom(X,Y)→hom(X,Z).

Let \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C be \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched. The finite products and coproducts, if they exist, are isomorphic via a canonical map. If they all exist, then this category is called an additive category. In particular, the nullary product and coproduct coincide, and we call the object zero object, denoted 0000.

By the universal property of products and coproducts, a map from the coproduct of some objects X_iXiX_iXi​ to their product is given by a matrix of morphisms f_{ij} : X_i \to X_jfij:Xi→Xjf_{ij} : X_i \to X_jfij​:Xi​→Xj​. We choose the identity matrix f_{ij} = \begin {cases} \operatorname {id} & (i = j) \\ 0 & (i \ne j) \end {cases}fij={id⁡(i=j)0(i≠j)f_{ij} = \begin {cases} \operatorname {id} & (i = j) \\ 0 & (i \ne j) \end {cases}fij​={id0​(i=j)(i=j)​ where 0000 is the additive neutral element in the abelian group \hom (X_i, X_j)hom⁡(Xi,Xj)\hom (X_i, X_j)hom(Xi​,Xj​). This gives a canonical map \coprod _i X_i \to \prod _i X_i∐iXi→∏iXi\coprod _i X_i \to \prod _i X_i∐i​Xi​→∏i​Xi​.

When there are finitely many objects involved, we can construct an inverse. Consider the morphisms \prod _i X_i \xrightarrow { \pi _j} X_j \xrightarrow { \iota _j} \coprod _i X_i.∏iXi→πjXj→ιj∐iXi.\prod _i X_i \xrightarrow { \pi _j} X_j \xrightarrow { \iota _j} \coprod _i X_i.i∏​Xi​πj​​Xj​ιj​​i∐​Xi​. We claim the sum of these morphisms is the desired inverse. To verify this, we compose them. Using bilinearity, we are reduced to showing that the coproduct and product of the identity map is the identity, which is true.

Due to this coincidence creating gadgets with two universal properties, the structure of additive categories are uniquely determined. This also means that we only need very mild conditions on functors to preserve the structures of an additive category.

frontmatter.title: Being an additive category is a property

mainmatter.p: Given a category, if it can be endowed with an \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enrichment that makes it an additive category, then it only has one possible enrichment. In particular, there is at most one way to turn a category into an additive category.
Notice that having finite products and coproducts is a property, and the canonical morphism between them being an isomorphism is also a property. These do not mention the enrichment structure.

With these properties satisfied, the addition structure on the \homhom⁡\homhom-sets are fixed. We claim that the additive neutral element is given by the composition X \to 0 \to Y,X→0→Y,X \to 0 \to Y,X→0→Y, and given two parallel morphisms f, g : X \to Yf,g:X→Yf, g : X \to Yf,g:X→Y, the following composition X \xrightarrow { \Delta } X \oplus X \xrightarrow {f \oplus g} Y \oplus Y \xrightarrow { \nabla } Y.X→ΔX⊕X→f⊕gY⊕Y→∇Y.X \xrightarrow { \Delta } X \oplus X \xrightarrow {f \oplus g} Y \oplus Y \xrightarrow { \nabla } Y.XΔ​X⊕Xf⊕g​Y⊕Y∇​Y. is equal to the addition f + gf+gf + gf+g. For disambiguation, we temporarily denote these constructions as 0'0′0'0′ and f +' gf+′gf +' gf+′g. By interpreting \oplus⊕\oplus⊕ as a product or a coproduct at appropriate times, it is easy to see that 0'0′0'0′ is indeed the neutral element for +'+′+'+′.

Recall that arrows X \oplus X \to Y \oplus YX⊕X→Y⊕YX \oplus X \to Y \oplus YX⊕X→Y⊕Y is given by a 2 \times 22×22 \times 22×2 matrix, and this correspondence is an abelian group isomorphism by general enriched category theory. f \oplus gf⊕gf \oplus gf⊕g comes from a diagonal matrix with f, gf,gf, gf,g as entries, so this operation is linear, which entails +'+′+'+′ is also linear. By the Eckmann–Hilton argument, the two addition operations must coincide.

Given two additive categories and a functor F : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D }F:C→DF : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D }F:C→D between them, the following are equivalent: The functor preserves finite products. The functor preserves finite coproducts. The functor is a homomorphism on the abelian groups \hom _{ \mathcal { C } }(X, Y)hom⁡C(X,Y)\hom _{ \mathcal { C } }(X, Y)homC​(X,Y), i.e. it is an \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched functor. In this case, we call the functor additive.

For the equivalence of the first two claims, we have a composition F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y),F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼ F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y),F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y),F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y), where the middle morphism comes from the canonical isomorphism X + Y \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y)X+Y→∼ F(X×Y)X + Y \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y)X+Y→∼F(X×Y). The first two claim is equivalent to the right and left arrows being iso, respectively. Recall that a morphism from a coproduct to a product is determined by a matrix of morphisms. With this fact and the functoriality of FFFF, we can compute that the composition is the canonical isomorphism from F(X) + F(Y)F(X)+F(Y)F(X) + F(Y)F(X)+F(Y) to F(X) \times F(Y)F(X)×F(Y)F(X) \times F(Y)F(X)×F(Y). Therefore the leftmost arrow being iso is equivalent to the rightmost arrow being iso.

Since the abelian group structure on morphisms is uniquely determined from the finite products and coproducts in an additive category, a functor satisfying the first two conditions automatically satisfies the third. Conversely, we need to prove the canonical maps F(1) \to 1F(1)→1F(1) \to 1F(1)→1 and F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y)F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y)F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y)F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y) are isomorphisms. For the first one, since 1111 is also the initial object, any morphism into it is automatically iso. For the second one, we again look at the diagram which composes to an isomorphism: F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y).F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼ F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y).F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y).F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y). Using the bilinearity of composition and that FFFF preserves addition on morphisms, we can verify that this provides a two-sided inverse.
In an adjunction F \dashv GF⊣GF \dashv GF⊣G, both functors are automatically additive.
Since the left adjoint preserves colimits, it preserves finite coproducts. Therefore by it is an additive functor. Dually, the right adjoint preserves limits, and is also additive.
Kernels and cokernels are also greatly simplified in additive categories.

frontmatter.title: Equalizers can be reduced to kernels in \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched categories

mainmatter.p: We can express equalizers with kernels (which are equalizers with the zero morphism).
We simply need to note that an equalizer for ffff and gggg is equivalent to an equalizer for (f-g)(f−g)(f-g)(f−g) and 0000, by bilinearity of composition.

Abelian categories are one step further from additive categories. Similar to the situation of abelian groups or modules, every morphism f : X \to Yf:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y has four key components, the image, the kernel, the coimage X / \ker fX/ker⁡fX / \ker fX/kerf, and the cokernel Y / \operatorname {im} fY/im⁡fY / \operatorname {im} fY/imf. The image is always identical with the coimage, representing the core part of the homomorphism. The kernel perfectly measures the failure of injectivity, and the cokernel perfectly measures the failure of surjectivity. This is in stark constrast with general maps, where the failure of injectivity may be heterogeneous, and thus cannot be simply characterized.

Given an additive category, it is an abelian category if the following condition holds:
Every morphism has a kernel and a cokernel.
Every monomorphism is the kernel of its cokernel.
Every epimorphism is the cokernel of its kernel.

The definition of abelian categories may look intimidating, but thinking of it as RRRR-modules is a very effective way to reduce mental load. In fact, the Freyd–Mitchell embedding theorem justifies this to some extent, allowing us to use familiar language such as taking and manipulating elements.

Although practically every important functor between additive categories is additive, the same cannot be said for abelian categories. Functors preserving the structure of abelian categories are called exact, but many functors fail to satisfy this for various reasons. One of the main endeavours of homological algebra is to characterize the failures of exactness, and study their consequences. This leads to intricate and beautiful structures emerging.

An additive functor F : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→BF : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→B between abelian categories is left exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions. It preserves kernels. It preserves finite limits. It preserves the exactness of sequences 0 \to A \to B \to C.0→A→B→C.0 \to A \to B \to C.0→A→B→C.

Dually, an additive functor is right exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions. It preserves cokernels. It preserves finite colimits. It preserves the exactness of sequences A \to B \to C \to 0.A→B→C→0.A \to B \to C \to 0.A→B→C→0. If a functor is both left exact and right exact, it is simply called an exact functor, which is equivalent to it preserving the exactness of sequences A \to B \to CA→B→CA \to B \to CA→B→C.
Since additive functors already preserves finite products, and kernels are equivalent to general coequalizers using the additive structure, the first two conditions are equivalent.

The sequence A \rightarrowtail B \to CA↣B→CA \rightarrowtail B \to CA↣B→C being exact is equivalent to AAAA being a kernel of B \to CB→CB \to CB→C. So the third condition is equivalent to the first. This completes the equivalence proof.

frontmatter.title: Equalizers can be reduced to kernels in \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched categories

mainmatter.p: We can express equalizers with kernels (which are equalizers with the zero morphism).
We simply need to note that an equalizer for ffff and gggg is equivalent to an equalizer for (f-g)(f−g)(f-g)(f−g) and 0000, by bilinearity of composition.

frontmatter.title: Kernel, image, cokernel and coimage of chain complexes

mainmatter.p: Given a chain map f_ \bullet : C_ \bullet \to D_ \bulletf∙:C∙→D∙f_ \bullet : C_ \bullet \to D_ \bulletf∙​:C∙​→D∙​, we can take the kernel, image, cokernel and coimage in each dimension, to obtain new chain complexes. It is a matter of unpacking and repacking quotients to verify that the relevant squares commute, rendering the following diagram of chain complexes.

mainmatter.p: An additive functor F : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→BF : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→B between abelian categories is left exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions. It preserves kernels. It preserves finite limits. It preserves the exactness of sequences 0 \to A \to B \to C.0→A→B→C.0 \to A \to B \to C.0→A→B→C.

Dually, an additive functor is right exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions. It preserves cokernels. It preserves finite colimits. It preserves the exactness of sequences A \to B \to C \to 0.A→B→C→0.A \to B \to C \to 0.A→B→C→0. If a functor is both left exact and right exact, it is simply called an exact functor, which is equivalent to it preserving the exactness of sequences A \to B \to CA→B→CA \to B \to CA→B→C.
Since additive functors already preserves finite products, and kernels are equivalent to general coequalizers using the additive structure, the first two conditions are equivalent.

The sequence A \rightarrowtail B \to CA↣B→CA \rightarrowtail B \to CA↣B→C being exact is equivalent to AAAA being a kernel of B \to CB→CB \to CB→C. So the third condition is equivalent to the first. This completes the equivalence proof.

frontmatter.title: Monomorphisms can be expressed using finite limits

mainmatter.p: Given a morphism f : X \to Yf:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y in an arbitrary category, we can express the condition of being monic using finite limits.
We claim that ffff being monic is equivalent to the following square being a pullback square:

mainmatter.p: For the forward implication, we consider the diagram

embedded-tex.embedded-tex-body: \begin {tikzcd} Z \\ & X & X \\ & X & Y \arrow ["f"', from=3-2, to=3-3] \arrow ["f", from=2-3, to=3-3] \arrow [" \operatorname {id} "', from=2-2, to=3-2] \arrow [" \operatorname {id} ", from=2-2, to=2-3] \arrow [" \lrcorner "{anchor=center, pos=0.125}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3] \arrow [dashed, from=1-1, to=2-2] \arrow ["g"', curve={height=6pt}, from=1-1, to=3-2] \arrow ["h", curve={height=-6pt}, from=1-1, to=2-3] \end {tikzcd}

On the other hand, if the diagram is a pullback, then for every pair of morphisms g, h : Z \rightrightarrows Xg,h:Z⇉Xg, h : Z \rightrightarrows Xg,h:Z⇉X, we can draw the diagram above, and obtain the dashed arrow k : Z \to Xk:Z→Xk : Z \to Xk:Z→X. The diagram commuting implies g = \operatorname {id} \circ k = hg=id⁡∘k=hg = \operatorname {id} \circ k = hg=id∘k=h.

frontmatter.title: \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched category

mainmatter.p: Given a category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C, an \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enrichment is given by abelian group structures on every hom-set, such that composition is linear in each argument. In other words, we have a homomorphism \hom (Y, Z) \otimes \hom (X, Y) \to \hom (X, Z)hom⁡(Y,Z)⊗hom⁡(X,Y)→hom⁡(X,Z)\hom (Y, Z) \otimes \hom (X, Y) \to \hom (X, Z)hom(Y,Z)⊗hom(X,Y)→hom(X,Z).
Any small abelian category can be realized as a full abelian subcategory of a category of left RRRR-modules for some ring RRRR.
(TODO)
It is fruitful to manipulate chain complexes as a whole. This allows us to neatly package some common algebraic operations.

frontmatter.title: Direct sum and product of chain complexes

mainmatter.p: Given a family of chain complexes C_{ \alpha , \bullet }Cα,∙C_{ \alpha , \bullet }Cα,∙​, we can take the direct sum in each dimension, giving D_ \bullet = \bigoplus _ \alpha C_{ \alpha , \bullet }D∙=⨁αCα,∙D_ \bullet = \bigoplus _ \alpha C_{ \alpha , \bullet }D∙​=⨁α​Cα,∙​, which is another chain complex. Dually, we can take the direct product \prod _ \alpha C_{ \alpha , \bullet }∏αCα,∙\prod _ \alpha C_{ \alpha , \bullet }∏α​Cα,∙​.

As another example, the consideration of quotienting out a subspace Y \subseteq XY⊆XY \subseteq XY⊆X naturally leads us to relative homology. We construct a chain complex by taking a quotient in each dimension: 0 \to C_ \bullet (Y) \hookrightarrow C_ \bullet (X) \to C_ \bullet (X, Y) \to 0.0→C∙(Y)↪C∙(X)→C∙(X,Y)→0.0 \to C_ \bullet (Y) \hookrightarrow C_ \bullet (X) \to C_ \bullet (X, Y) \to 0.0→C∙​(Y)↪C∙​(X)→C∙​(X,Y)→0. These maps commute with the boundary maps, so it can be regarded as an exact sequence of chain complexes. Thus we are led to the following definitions.

A bicomplex is a chain complex of chain complexes. More specifically, we have a grid of objects A_{m, n}Am,nA_{m, n}Am,n​, vertical maps d : A_{m, n} \to A_{m, n-1}d:Am,n→Am,n−1d : A_{m, n} \to A_{m, n-1}d:Am,n​→Am,n−1​ and horizontal maps \delta : A_{m, n} \to A_{m-1, n}δ:Am,n→Am−1,n\delta : A_{m, n} \to A_{m-1, n}δ:Am,n​→Am−1,n​. Every square in the grid commutes, and d^2 = \delta ^2 = 0d2=δ2=0d^2 = \delta ^2 = 0d2=δ2=0.

Each column A_{m, \bullet }Am,∙A_{m, \bullet }Am,∙​ in the bicomplex is a chain complex, and \deltaδ\deltaδ are chain maps between the column complexes. Similarly, each row forms a chain complex, and dddd are chain maps between the row complexes.
An exact sequence of chain complexes C_{m, \bullet }Cm,∙C_{m, \bullet }Cm,∙​ is a bicomplex such that the rows are exact.

frontmatter.title: Kernel, image, cokernel and coimage of chain complexes

mainmatter.p: Given a chain map f_ \bullet : C_ \bullet \to D_ \bulletf∙:C∙→D∙f_ \bullet : C_ \bullet \to D_ \bulletf∙​:C∙​→D∙​, we can take the kernel, image, cokernel and coimage in each dimension, to obtain new chain complexes. It is a matter of unpacking and repacking quotients to verify that the relevant squares commute, rendering the following diagram of chain complexes.

mainmatter.p: Since many operations on abelian groups and RRRR-modules can be performed on chain complexes, we wish to axiomatize an abstract notion to encapsulate them all. This motivates the definition of additive and abelian categories. We can use the three examples mentioned above as the source for intuitions for abelian categories.

First, we wish to let the morphisms form abelian groups. This turns out to have a surprising impact on the structure of categories, the most important of which is the coincidence of finite products and coproducts.

frontmatter.title: \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched category

mainmatter.p: Given a category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C, an \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enrichment is given by abelian group structures on every hom-set, such that composition is linear in each argument. In other words, we have a homomorphism \hom (Y, Z) \otimes \hom (X, Y) \to \hom (X, Z)hom⁡(Y,Z)⊗hom⁡(X,Y)→hom⁡(X,Z)\hom (Y, Z) \otimes \hom (X, Y) \to \hom (X, Z)hom(Y,Z)⊗hom(X,Y)→hom(X,Z).

Let \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C be \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched. The finite products and coproducts, if they exist, are isomorphic via a canonical map. If they all exist, then this category is called an additive category. In particular, the nullary product and coproduct coincide, and we call the object zero object, denoted 0000.

By the universal property of products and coproducts, a map from the coproduct of some objects X_iXiX_iXi​ to their product is given by a matrix of morphisms f_{ij} : X_i \to X_jfij:Xi→Xjf_{ij} : X_i \to X_jfij​:Xi​→Xj​. We choose the identity matrix f_{ij} = \begin {cases} \operatorname {id} & (i = j) \\ 0 & (i \ne j) \end {cases}fij={id⁡(i=j)0(i≠j)f_{ij} = \begin {cases} \operatorname {id} & (i = j) \\ 0 & (i \ne j) \end {cases}fij​={id0​(i=j)(i=j)​ where 0000 is the additive neutral element in the abelian group \hom (X_i, X_j)hom⁡(Xi,Xj)\hom (X_i, X_j)hom(Xi​,Xj​). This gives a canonical map \coprod _i X_i \to \prod _i X_i∐iXi→∏iXi\coprod _i X_i \to \prod _i X_i∐i​Xi​→∏i​Xi​.

When there are finitely many objects involved, we can construct an inverse. Consider the morphisms \prod _i X_i \xrightarrow { \pi _j} X_j \xrightarrow { \iota _j} \coprod _i X_i.∏iXi→πjXj→ιj∐iXi.\prod _i X_i \xrightarrow { \pi _j} X_j \xrightarrow { \iota _j} \coprod _i X_i.i∏​Xi​πj​​Xj​ιj​​i∐​Xi​. We claim the sum of these morphisms is the desired inverse. To verify this, we compose them. Using bilinearity, we are reduced to showing that the coproduct and product of the identity map is the identity, which is true.

Due to this coincidence creating gadgets with two universal properties, the structure of additive categories are uniquely determined. This also means that we only need very mild conditions on functors to preserve the structures of an additive category.

frontmatter.title: Being an additive category is a property

mainmatter.p: Given a category, if it can be endowed with an \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enrichment that makes it an additive category, then it only has one possible enrichment. In particular, there is at most one way to turn a category into an additive category.
Notice that having finite products and coproducts is a property, and the canonical morphism between them being an isomorphism is also a property. These do not mention the enrichment structure.

With these properties satisfied, the addition structure on the \homhom⁡\homhom-sets are fixed. We claim that the additive neutral element is given by the composition X \to 0 \to Y,X→0→Y,X \to 0 \to Y,X→0→Y, and given two parallel morphisms f, g : X \to Yf,g:X→Yf, g : X \to Yf,g:X→Y, the following composition X \xrightarrow { \Delta } X \oplus X \xrightarrow {f \oplus g} Y \oplus Y \xrightarrow { \nabla } Y.X→ΔX⊕X→f⊕gY⊕Y→∇Y.X \xrightarrow { \Delta } X \oplus X \xrightarrow {f \oplus g} Y \oplus Y \xrightarrow { \nabla } Y.XΔ​X⊕Xf⊕g​Y⊕Y∇​Y. is equal to the addition f + gf+gf + gf+g. For disambiguation, we temporarily denote these constructions as 0'0′0'0′ and f +' gf+′gf +' gf+′g. By interpreting \oplus⊕\oplus⊕ as a product or a coproduct at appropriate times, it is easy to see that 0'0′0'0′ is indeed the neutral element for +'+′+'+′.

Recall that arrows X \oplus X \to Y \oplus YX⊕X→Y⊕YX \oplus X \to Y \oplus YX⊕X→Y⊕Y is given by a 2 \times 22×22 \times 22×2 matrix, and this correspondence is an abelian group isomorphism by general enriched category theory. f \oplus gf⊕gf \oplus gf⊕g comes from a diagonal matrix with f, gf,gf, gf,g as entries, so this operation is linear, which entails +'+′+'+′ is also linear. By the Eckmann–Hilton argument, the two addition operations must coincide.

Given two additive categories and a functor F : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D }F:C→DF : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D }F:C→D between them, the following are equivalent: The functor preserves finite products. The functor preserves finite coproducts. The functor is a homomorphism on the abelian groups \hom _{ \mathcal { C } }(X, Y)hom⁡C(X,Y)\hom _{ \mathcal { C } }(X, Y)homC​(X,Y), i.e. it is an \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched functor. In this case, we call the functor additive.

For the equivalence of the first two claims, we have a composition F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y),F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼ F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y),F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y),F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y), where the middle morphism comes from the canonical isomorphism X + Y \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y)X+Y→∼ F(X×Y)X + Y \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y)X+Y→∼F(X×Y). The first two claim is equivalent to the right and left arrows being iso, respectively. Recall that a morphism from a coproduct to a product is determined by a matrix of morphisms. With this fact and the functoriality of FFFF, we can compute that the composition is the canonical isomorphism from F(X) + F(Y)F(X)+F(Y)F(X) + F(Y)F(X)+F(Y) to F(X) \times F(Y)F(X)×F(Y)F(X) \times F(Y)F(X)×F(Y). Therefore the leftmost arrow being iso is equivalent to the rightmost arrow being iso.

Since the abelian group structure on morphisms is uniquely determined from the finite products and coproducts in an additive category, a functor satisfying the first two conditions automatically satisfies the third. Conversely, we need to prove the canonical maps F(1) \to 1F(1)→1F(1) \to 1F(1)→1 and F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y)F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y)F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y)F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y) are isomorphisms. For the first one, since 1111 is also the initial object, any morphism into it is automatically iso. For the second one, we again look at the diagram which composes to an isomorphism: F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y).F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼ F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y).F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y).F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y). Using the bilinearity of composition and that FFFF preserves addition on morphisms, we can verify that this provides a two-sided inverse.
In an adjunction F \dashv GF⊣GF \dashv GF⊣G, both functors are automatically additive.
Since the left adjoint preserves colimits, it preserves finite coproducts. Therefore by it is an additive functor. Dually, the right adjoint preserves limits, and is also additive.
Kernels and cokernels are also greatly simplified in additive categories.

frontmatter.title: Equalizers can be reduced to kernels in \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched categories

mainmatter.p: We can express equalizers with kernels (which are equalizers with the zero morphism).
We simply need to note that an equalizer for ffff and gggg is equivalent to an equalizer for (f-g)(f−g)(f-g)(f−g) and 0000, by bilinearity of composition.

Abelian categories are one step further from additive categories. Similar to the situation of abelian groups or modules, every morphism f : X \to Yf:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y has four key components, the image, the kernel, the coimage X / \ker fX/ker⁡fX / \ker fX/kerf, and the cokernel Y / \operatorname {im} fY/im⁡fY / \operatorname {im} fY/imf. The image is always identical with the coimage, representing the core part of the homomorphism. The kernel perfectly measures the failure of injectivity, and the cokernel perfectly measures the failure of surjectivity. This is in stark constrast with general maps, where the failure of injectivity may be heterogeneous, and thus cannot be simply characterized.

Given an additive category, it is an abelian category if the following condition holds:
Every morphism has a kernel and a cokernel.
Every monomorphism is the kernel of its cokernel.
Every epimorphism is the cokernel of its kernel.

The definition of abelian categories may look intimidating, but thinking of it as RRRR-modules is a very effective way to reduce mental load. In fact, the Freyd–Mitchell embedding theorem justifies this to some extent, allowing us to use familiar language such as taking and manipulating elements.

Although practically every important functor between additive categories is additive, the same cannot be said for abelian categories. Functors preserving the structure of abelian categories are called exact, but many functors fail to satisfy this for various reasons. One of the main endeavours of homological algebra is to characterize the failures of exactness, and study their consequences. This leads to intricate and beautiful structures emerging.

An additive functor F : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→BF : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→B between abelian categories is left exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions. It preserves kernels. It preserves finite limits. It preserves the exactness of sequences 0 \to A \to B \to C.0→A→B→C.0 \to A \to B \to C.0→A→B→C.

Dually, an additive functor is right exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions. It preserves cokernels. It preserves finite colimits. It preserves the exactness of sequences A \to B \to C \to 0.A→B→C→0.A \to B \to C \to 0.A→B→C→0. If a functor is both left exact and right exact, it is simply called an exact functor, which is equivalent to it preserving the exactness of sequences A \to B \to CA→B→CA \to B \to CA→B→C.
Since additive functors already preserves finite products, and kernels are equivalent to general coequalizers using the additive structure, the first two conditions are equivalent.

The sequence A \rightarrowtail B \to CA↣B→CA \rightarrowtail B \to CA↣B→C being exact is equivalent to AAAA being a kernel of B \to CB→CB \to CB→C. So the third condition is equivalent to the first. This completes the equivalence proof.

Every epimorphism is the cokernel of its kernel.

mainmatter.p: A short exact sequence is an exact sequence with all but three consecutive terms being zero. It is often written as 0 \to A \to B \to C \to 0.0→A→B→C→0.0 \to A \to B \to C \to 0.0→A→B→C→0. Short exact sequence describes how BBBB is made up of a subobject AAAA and a quotient CCCC.

Some sources require a bicomplex to have anti-commuting squares. In this way, the total complex has the simpler differential \partial = d + \delta∂=d+δ\partial = d + \delta∂=d+δ. These two definitions are convertible by flipping the signs of the horizontal boundary maps in every other row.

Given a bicomplex C_{ \bullet , \bullet }C∙,∙C_{ \bullet , \bullet }C∙,∙​, we can collapse it into a chain complex in two ways. In either way, C_{p, q}Cp,qC_{p, q}Cp,q​ is contained in the total complex at degree (m+n)(m+n)(m+n)(m+n). We can use the direct sum to combine them: \operatorname {Tot} ^ \oplus (C)_n = \bigoplus _{n = p+q} C_{p, q},Tot⁡⊕(C)n=⨁n=p+qCp,q,\operatorname {Tot} ^ \oplus (C)_n = \bigoplus _{n = p+q} C_{p, q},Tot⊕(C)n​=n=p+q⨁​Cp,q​, or the direct product: \operatorname {Tot} ^ \Pi (C)_n = \prod _{n=p+q} C_{p,q}.Tot⁡Π(C)n=∏n=p+qCp,q.\operatorname {Tot} ^ \Pi (C)_n = \prod _{n=p+q} C_{p,q}.TotΠ(C)n​=n=p+q∏​Cp,q​.

The total differential acts on elements in C_{p, q}Cp,qC_{p, q}Cp,q​ by \partial (x) = d(x) + (-1)^q \delta (x),∂(x)=d(x)+(−1)qδ(x),\partial (x) = d(x) + (-1)^q \delta (x),∂(x)=d(x)+(−1)qδ(x), where dddd is the vertical map, and \deltaδ\deltaδ the horizontal map. The sign here is to ensure that \partial ^2 = 0∂2=0\partial ^2 = 0∂2=0.
If all the homology groups vanish, then the chain complex is said fo be acyclic or exact. Equivalently, every cycle is a boundary.

Since the boundary subgroup in one dimension can also be considered as a quotient in a lower dimension, it may be beneficial to identify the two in a visualization. This leads to the following picture. Regions appearing to the right are to be considered as quotients, and those to the left as subobjects. Further development of this visualization scheme can be seen here.

mainmatter.p: We chose to draw circles to emphasize the individual chain groups. In more complicated situations, it is more convenient to draw a chain of rectangles, with each chain group spanning three rectangular regions. We would then need other means to convey the confines of each object.

Chain complexes arose from combinatorial topology, in the form of a sequence of abelian groups C_nCnC_nCn​ freely generated by cells of dimension nnnn (i.e. encoding the formal sums of cells), and a boundary operator d_n : C_n \to C_{n-1}dn:Cn→Cn−1d_n : C_n \to C_{n-1}dn​:Cn​→Cn−1​. The critical feature of the operator is d_{n-1} \circ d_n = 0,dn−1∘dn=0,d_{n-1} \circ d_n = 0,dn−1​∘dn​=0, simply written as d^2 = 0d2=0d^2 = 0d2=0, reflecting a deep geometric phenomenon that the boundary of a shape doesn’t have any boundary itself.

A chain complex of abelian groups is given by a sequence of abelian groups G_ \bulletG∙G_ \bulletG∙​ together with homomorphisms d_n : G_n \to G_{n-1}dn:Gn→Gn−1d_n : G_n \to G_{n-1}dn​:Gn​→Gn−1​, such that d_{n-1} \circ d_n = 0dn−1∘dn=0d_{n-1} \circ d_n = 0dn−1​∘dn​=0.
This is eligible to immediate generalization.

frontmatter.title: Chain complex of RRRR-modules

mainmatter.p: A chain complex of RRRR-modules is given by a sequence of modules M_ \bulletM∙M_ \bulletM∙​ together with RRRR-linear maps d_n : R_n \to R_{n-1}dn:Rn→Rn−1d_n : R_n \to R_{n-1}dn​:Rn​→Rn−1​, such that d_{n-1} \circ d_n = 0dn−1∘dn=0d_{n-1} \circ d_n = 0dn−1​∘dn​=0.

Homology can be defined using this algebraic information, without any further reference to topology. Homological algebra is then the algebraic part of reasoning utilized in algebraic topology, repackaged as a stand-alone branch of mathematics. We recall some basics of what we’ve got from algebraic topology.

Given a chain complex, the cycles Z_nZnZ_nZn​ of dimension nnnn are given by the kernel of d_n : C_n \to C_{n-1}dn:Cn→Cn−1d_n : C_n \to C_{n-1}dn​:Cn​→Cn−1​. The equation d^2 = 0d2=0d^2 = 0d2=0 is equivalent to 0 \subseteq B_n \subseteq Z_n \subseteq C_n.0⊆Bn⊆Zn⊆Cn.0 \subseteq B_n \subseteq Z_n \subseteq C_n.0⊆Bn​⊆Zn​⊆Cn​. We can define quotient groups to measure the gaps in the inclusion chain. By the homomorphism theorem, the quotient C_n / Z_nCn/ZnC_n / Z_nCn​/Zn​ is isomorphic to the image of d_ndnd_ndn​, which is the next boundary B_{n-1}Bn−1B_{n-1}Bn−1​. On the other hand, the homology groups H_n(C)Hn(C)H_n(C)Hn​(C) are defined as the quotient Z_n/B_nZn/BnZ_n/B_nZn​/Bn​.

Since the boundary subgroup in one dimension can also be considered as a quotient in a lower dimension, it may be beneficial to identify the two in a visualization. A chain map is a quasi-isomorphism if it induces isomorphisms on the homology groups.

It is fruitful to manipulate chain complexes as a whole. This allows us to neatly package some common algebraic operations.

frontmatter.title: Direct sum and product of chain complexes

mainmatter.p: Given a family of chain complexes C_{ \alpha , \bullet }Cα,∙C_{ \alpha , \bullet }Cα,∙​, we can take the direct sum in each dimension, giving D_ \bullet = \bigoplus _ \alpha C_{ \alpha , \bullet }D∙=⨁αCα,∙D_ \bullet = \bigoplus _ \alpha C_{ \alpha , \bullet }D∙​=⨁α​Cα,∙​, which is another chain complex. Dually, we can take the direct product \prod _ \alpha C_{ \alpha , \bullet }∏αCα,∙\prod _ \alpha C_{ \alpha , \bullet }∏α​Cα,∙​.

As another example, the consideration of quotienting out a subspace Y \subseteq XY⊆XY \subseteq XY⊆X naturally leads us to relative homology. We construct a chain complex by taking a quotient in each dimension: 0 \to C_ \bullet (Y) \hookrightarrow C_ \bullet (X) \to C_ \bullet (X, Y) \to 0.0→C∙(Y)↪C∙(X)→C∙(X,Y)→0.0 \to C_ \bullet (Y) \hookrightarrow C_ \bullet (X) \to C_ \bullet (X, Y) \to 0.0→C∙​(Y)↪C∙​(X)→C∙​(X,Y)→0. These maps commute with the boundary maps, so it can be regarded as an exact sequence of chain complexes. Thus we are led to the following definitions.

A bicomplex is a chain complex of chain complexes. More specifically, we have a grid of objects A_{m, n}Am,nA_{m, n}Am,n​, vertical maps d : A_{m, n} \to A_{m, n-1}d:Am,n→Am,n−1d : A_{m, n} \to A_{m, n-1}d:Am,n​→Am,n−1​ and horizontal maps \delta : A_{m, n} \to A_{m-1, n}δ:Am,n→Am−1,n\delta : A_{m, n} \to A_{m-1, n}δ:Am,n​→Am−1,n​. Every square in the grid commutes, and d^2 = \delta ^2 = 0d2=δ2=0d^2 = \delta ^2 = 0d2=δ2=0.

Each column A_{m, \bullet }Am,∙A_{m, \bullet }Am,∙​ in the bicomplex is a chain complex, and \deltaδ\deltaδ are chain maps between the column complexes. Similarly, each row forms a chain complex, and dddd are chain maps between the row complexes.
An exact sequence of chain complexes C_{m, \bullet }Cm,∙C_{m, \bullet }Cm,∙​ is a bicomplex such that the rows are exact.

frontmatter.title: Kernel, image, cokernel and coimage of chain complexes

mainmatter.p: Given a chain map f_ \bullet : C_ \bullet \to D_ \bulletf∙:C∙→D∙f_ \bullet : C_ \bullet \to D_ \bulletf∙​:C∙​→D∙​, we can take the kernel, image, cokernel and coimage in each dimension, to obtain new chain complexes. It is a matter of unpacking and repacking quotients to verify that the relevant squares commute, rendering the following diagram of chain complexes.

embedded-tex.embedded-tex-preamble: \usepackage{mlmodern, tikz, tikz-cd, quiver, mathtools, amssymb, stmaryrd, mathrsfs}

mainmatter.p: Since many operations on abelian groups and RRRR-modules can be performed on chain complexes, we wish to axiomatize an abstract notion to encapsulate them all. This motivates the definition of additive and abelian categories. We can use the three examples mentioned above as the source for intuitions for abelian categories.

First, we wish to let the morphisms form abelian groups. This turns out to have a surprising impact on the structure of categories, the most important of which is the coincidence of finite products and coproducts.

frontmatter.title: \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched category

mainmatter.p: Given a category \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C, an \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enrichment is given by abelian group structures on every hom-set, such that composition is linear in each argument. In other words, we have a homomorphism \hom (Y, Z) \otimes \hom (X, Y) \to \hom (X, Z)hom⁡(Y,Z)⊗hom⁡(X,Y)→hom⁡(X,Z)\hom (Y, Z) \otimes \hom (X, Y) \to \hom (X, Z)hom(Y,Z)⊗hom(X,Y)→hom(X,Z).

Let \mathcal { C }C\mathcal { C }C be \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched. The finite products and coproducts, if they exist, are isomorphic via a canonical map. If they all exist, then this category is called an additive category. In particular, the nullary product and coproduct coincide, and we call the object zero object, denoted 0000.

By the universal property of products and coproducts, a map from the coproduct of some objects X_iXiX_iXi​ to their product is given by a matrix of morphisms f_{ij} : X_i \to X_jfij:Xi→Xjf_{ij} : X_i \to X_jfij​:Xi​→Xj​. We choose the identity matrix f_{ij} = \begin {cases} \operatorname {id} & (i = j) \\ 0 & (i \ne j) \end {cases}fij={id⁡(i=j)0(i≠j)f_{ij} = \begin {cases} \operatorname {id} & (i = j) \\ 0 & (i \ne j) \end {cases}fij​={id0​(i=j)(i=j)​ where 0000 is the additive neutral element in the abelian group \hom (X_i, X_j)hom⁡(Xi,Xj)\hom (X_i, X_j)hom(Xi​,Xj​). This gives a canonical map \coprod _i X_i \to \prod _i X_i∐iXi→∏iXi\coprod _i X_i \to \prod _i X_i∐i​Xi​→∏i​Xi​.

When there are finitely many objects involved, we can construct an inverse. Consider the morphisms \prod _i X_i \xrightarrow { \pi _j} X_j \xrightarrow { \iota _j} \coprod _i X_i.∏iXi→πjXj→ιj∐iXi.\prod _i X_i \xrightarrow { \pi _j} X_j \xrightarrow { \iota _j} \coprod _i X_i.i∏​Xi​πj​​Xj​ιj​​i∐​Xi​. We claim the sum of these morphisms is the desired inverse. To verify this, we compose them. Using bilinearity, we are reduced to showing that the coproduct and product of the identity map is the identity, which is true.

Due to this coincidence creating gadgets with two universal properties, the structure of additive categories are uniquely determined. This also means that we only need very mild conditions on functors to preserve the structures of an additive category.

frontmatter.title: Being an additive category is a property

mainmatter.p: Given a category, if it can be endowed with an \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enrichment that makes it an additive category, then it only has one possible enrichment. In particular, there is at most one way to turn a category into an additive category.
Notice that having finite products and coproducts is a property, and the canonical morphism between them being an isomorphism is also a property. These do not mention the enrichment structure.

With these properties satisfied, the addition structure on the \homhom⁡\homhom-sets are fixed. We claim that the additive neutral element is given by the composition X \to 0 \to Y,X→0→Y,X \to 0 \to Y,X→0→Y, and given two parallel morphisms f, g : X \to Yf,g:X→Yf, g : X \to Yf,g:X→Y, the following composition X \xrightarrow { \Delta } X \oplus X \xrightarrow {f \oplus g} Y \oplus Y \xrightarrow { \nabla } Y.X→ΔX⊕X→f⊕gY⊕Y→∇Y.X \xrightarrow { \Delta } X \oplus X \xrightarrow {f \oplus g} Y \oplus Y \xrightarrow { \nabla } Y.XΔ​X⊕Xf⊕g​Y⊕Y∇​Y. is equal to the addition f + gf+gf + gf+g. For disambiguation, we temporarily denote these constructions as 0'0′0'0′ and f +' gf+′gf +' gf+′g. By interpreting \oplus⊕\oplus⊕ as a product or a coproduct at appropriate times, it is easy to see that 0'0′0'0′ is indeed the neutral element for +'+′+'+′.

Recall that arrows X \oplus X \to Y \oplus YX⊕X→Y⊕YX \oplus X \to Y \oplus YX⊕X→Y⊕Y is given by a 2 \times 22×22 \times 22×2 matrix, and this correspondence is an abelian group isomorphism by general enriched category theory. f \oplus gf⊕gf \oplus gf⊕g comes from a diagonal matrix with f, gf,gf, gf,g as entries, so this operation is linear, which entails +'+′+'+′ is also linear. By the Eckmann–Hilton argument, the two addition operations must coincide.

Given two additive categories and a functor F : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D }F:C→DF : \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D }F:C→D between them, the following are equivalent: The functor preserves finite products. The functor preserves finite coproducts. The functor is a homomorphism on the abelian groups \hom _{ \mathcal { C } }(X, Y)hom⁡C(X,Y)\hom _{ \mathcal { C } }(X, Y)homC​(X,Y), i.e. it is an \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched functor. In this case, we call the functor additive.

For the equivalence of the first two claims, we have a composition F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y),F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼ F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y),F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y),F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y), where the middle morphism comes from the canonical isomorphism X + Y \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y)X+Y→∼ F(X×Y)X + Y \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y)X+Y→∼F(X×Y). The first two claim is equivalent to the right and left arrows being iso, respectively. Recall that a morphism from a coproduct to a product is determined by a matrix of morphisms. With this fact and the functoriality of FFFF, we can compute that the composition is the canonical isomorphism from F(X) + F(Y)F(X)+F(Y)F(X) + F(Y)F(X)+F(Y) to F(X) \times F(Y)F(X)×F(Y)F(X) \times F(Y)F(X)×F(Y). Therefore the leftmost arrow being iso is equivalent to the rightmost arrow being iso.

Since the abelian group structure on morphisms is uniquely determined from the finite products and coproducts in an additive category, a functor satisfying the first two conditions automatically satisfies the third. Conversely, we need to prove the canonical maps F(1) \to 1F(1)→1F(1) \to 1F(1)→1 and F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y)F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y)F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y)F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y) are isomorphisms. For the first one, since 1111 is also the initial object, any morphism into it is automatically iso. For the second one, we again look at the diagram which composes to an isomorphism: F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y).F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼ F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y).F(X) + F(Y) \to F(X + Y) \stackrel { \sim \, }{ \to } F(X \times Y) \to F(X) \times F(Y).F(X)+F(Y)→F(X+Y)→∼F(X×Y)→F(X)×F(Y). Using the bilinearity of composition and that FFFF preserves addition on morphisms, we can verify that this provides a two-sided inverse.
In an adjunction F \dashv GF⊣GF \dashv GF⊣G, both functors are automatically additive.
Since the left adjoint preserves colimits, it preserves finite coproducts. Therefore by it is an additive functor. Dually, the right adjoint preserves limits, and is also additive.
Kernels and cokernels are also greatly simplified in additive categories.

frontmatter.title: Equalizers can be reduced to kernels in \mathsf { Ab }Ab\mathsf { Ab }Ab-enriched categories

mainmatter.p: We can express equalizers with kernels (which are equalizers with the zero morphism).
We simply need to note that an equalizer for ffff and gggg is equivalent to an equalizer for (f-g)(f−g)(f-g)(f−g) and 0000, by bilinearity of composition.

Abelian categories are one step further from additive categories. Similar to the situation of abelian groups or modules, every morphism f : X \to Yf:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y has four key components, the image, the kernel, the coimage X / \ker fX/ker⁡fX / \ker fX/kerf, and the cokernel Y / \operatorname {im} fY/im⁡fY / \operatorname {im} fY/imf. The image is always identical with the coimage, representing the core part of the homomorphism. The kernel perfectly measures the failure of injectivity, and the cokernel perfectly measures the failure of surjectivity. This is in stark constrast with general maps, where the failure of injectivity may be heterogeneous, and thus cannot be simply characterized.

Given an additive category, it is an abelian category if the following condition holds:
Every morphism has a kernel and a cokernel.
Every monomorphism is the kernel of its cokernel.
Every epimorphism is the cokernel of its kernel.

The definition of abelian categories may look intimidating, but thinking of it as RRRR-modules is a very effective way to reduce mental load. In fact, the Freyd–Mitchell embedding theorem justifies this to some extent, allowing us to use familiar language such as taking and manipulating elements.

Although practically every important functor between additive categories is additive, the same cannot be said for abelian categories. Functors preserving the structure of abelian categories are called exact, but many functors fail to satisfy this for various reasons. One of the main endeavours of homological algebra is to characterize the failures of exactness, and study their consequences. This leads to intricate and beautiful structures emerging.

An additive functor F : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→BF : \mathcal { A } \to \mathcal { B }F:A→B between abelian categories is left exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions. It preserves kernels. It preserves finite limits. It preserves the exactness of sequences 0 \to A \to B \to C.0→A→B→C.0 \to A \to B \to C.0→A→B→C.

Dually, an additive functor is right exact if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions. It preserves cokernels. It preserves finite colimits. It preserves the exactness of sequences A \to B \to C \to 0.A→B→C→0.A \to B \to C \to 0.A→B→C→0. If a functor is both left exact and right exact, it is simply called an exact functor, which is equivalent to it preserving the exactness of sequences A \to B \to CA→B→CA \to B \to CA→B→C.
Since additive functors already preserves finite products, and kernels are equivalent to general coequalizers using the additive structure, the first two conditions are equivalent.

The sequence A \rightarrowtail B \to CA↣B→CA \rightarrowtail B \to CA↣B→C being exact is equivalent to AAAA being a kernel of B \to CB→CB \to CB→C. So the third condition is equivalent to the first. This completes the equivalence proof.

In an abelian category, an object PPPP is projective iff for every morphism P \to BP→BP \to BP→B can be lifted through an epimorphism A \twoheadrightarrow BA↠BA \twoheadrightarrow BA↠B, i.e. there exists a (non-unique) morphism P \to AP→AP \to AP→A making the triangle commute.

Projective objects are defined to capture a key property of free objects. For an arbitrary abelian group PPPP, lifting a map P \to BP→BP \to BP→B through an epimorphism requires us to pick a lifting for every generator, such that the relations between the generators still hold after lifting. If such a thing can always be done, then we may say that the relations, or tangling between generators are practically non-existent. A projective object can thus be reguarded as generated by some elements with zero or undetectable “tangling”.

I try to adhere to several principles when composing trees.

ul.li: If a part of a proof has an easy constructive phrasing, use it and avoid classical reasoning. But if it requires some complication, then the classical way is used.

Avoid abstraction leaks. Even if A is defined as B, do not use them interchangeably. For instance, an ideal is defined as a subset of a ring satisfying certain conditions. But we will insist on writing ideals as numbers, for example saying \mathfrak { a } \mid xa∣x\mathfrak { a } \mid xa∣x instead of x \in \mathfrak { a }x∈ax \in \mathfrak { a }x∈a. This is not too heretic, since algebraic number theory already uses this kind of notation. Similarly, although prime ideals corresponds to points in \operatorname {Spec} (A)Spec⁡(A)\operatorname {Spec} (A)Spec(A), we do not identify them.
Apply unbiased terminology and negative thinking.
